context.text: Well, this original action by the state of Mississippi against the state of Arkansas is one to fix and determine the boundary line between the two states in the old bed of the Mississippi river between the ends of what is now known as the Tarpley Cut-off in the area where Arkansas' Chicot County and Mississippi's Washington County adjoin.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We granted Mississippi's motion to file a Bill of Complaint and referred the matter to a special master.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In a opinion filed today, we discuss three particular aspects of the evidence namely these some ancient tree stumps, some testimony has to the nature of the soil on Luna Bar and testimony as to elevations.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The majority of the Court credit the witnesses for Mississippi and conclude that their testimony greatly buttresses the prima facie case, which Arkansas and Mississippi had made out.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The entry of a decree is directed accordingly.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Insofar, as the provision regulates the access to the ballot by the new parties and independent candidates, we affirm the judgment below which sustained the statutes.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We also think that District Court dealt with the challenge to the Texas campaign-financing law satisfactorily and that court sustained it and we affirm in that respect.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But the Texas statutes also deny the benefits of the absentee ballot to new or minority parties and in this respect, we think the judgment below should be vacated before further proceedings are consistent with the principle stated in the opinion that we have filed today.

context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The case involves an aspect of the relationship between a statute of limitations and the provisions of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23, regulating class actions in the Federal Courts.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We hold that in the circumstances of this case, from the date Utah’s suit was filed until the date of the District Court’s order holding that a class suit was inappropriate, the statute of limitations was told as to members of the punitive class.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Since they sought to intervene eight days after the District Court’s order, and since there were 11 days yet to run at the time of the order, their motion to intervene was timely.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals of the Ninth Circuit is affirmed.

context.text: The disposition of number 72-1118, Arnett against Kennedy will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case involves the constitutionality of certain procedural and substantive rules governing federal employees embodied in the Lloyd-La Follette Act and in regulations promulgated by the Civil Service Commission.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Because we have a fractionated court on one of the issues, it may take a little longer than usual to describe the situation.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: An employee receives full back pay if he has re-instated.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: On the issue of whether or not the regulations are vague or overboard, six of us agree in an opinion, which I -- for reasons stated in an opinion, which I have authored and filed with the clerk that there is no constitutional infirmity in these regulations.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: On the procedural due process issue as to whether or not the procedures provided by the regulations and by the Act for hearing prior to and after suspension or discharge.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In an opinion in which I have authored and which only the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Stewart joined, we conclude that in granting federal employees like appellee, the right not to be discharged except for cause, and at the same time conditioning that grant by withholding the procedural guarantees to which appellee insists he has the right.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Congress did not create a property interest requiring procedural protection under the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment beyond that already afforded.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We also conclude that existing post termination hearing procedures adequately protect the liberty interest to federal employees and not being wrongfully stigmatized by untrue and unsupported administrative charges.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We also conclude that existing post termination hearing procedures adequately protect the liberty interest to federal employees and not being wrongfully stigmatized by untrue and unsupported administrative charges.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Finally we conclude that the Act’s removal standard is neither impermissibly vague, nor overbroad.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Since it describes as explicitly as is feasible, the wide variety of factual situations in which employee conduct including speech might justify removal for cause.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell, who Mr. Justice Blackmun joins, agrees with the reasons given in the opinion which I have written on the overbreadth  and vagueness part of the case.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They would hold that the, with respect to the due process issue, appellee, as a non-probationary federal employee, who could be discharged only for a cause, had a legitimate claim of entitlement to a property interest under the Fifth amendment and his employment could not be terminated without notice and a full evidentiary hearing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: On the other hand the Government, as an employer, must have discretion expeditiously to remove employees who hinder efficient operation.

Baker v. Gold Seal Liquors, Inc..case_name: Baker v. Gold Seal Liquors, Inc.
Baker v. Gold Seal Liquors, Inc..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 17, 1974

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The trustee had his judgment for his freight charges and the shipper for his cargo damages and the question arose whether the shipper could set off his judgment for the cargo damage against what he owed to railroad for freight charges and pay over only the balance.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Court of Appeals held that the shipper could set off on judgment against the other.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: In an opinion that Mr. Justice Douglas has written for the Court, we reverse that judgment and hold that in the circumstances present here in this railroad reorganization, the set off was improper.

context.speaker: Byron R. White

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell joined him and Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - APRIL 15, 1974

context.speaker: James V. Ryan
context.text: I may want to think in this specific case, Your Honor, it would be the same.

context.speaker: James V. Ryan
context.text: It would be like Matthews versus Headley case which I have cited in my brief where you can by -- there is no question here that if there is a recovery here of the seven million dollars that Amoskeag has received a windfall.

context.speaker: James V. Ryan
context.text: There is no doubt about that.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Something would depend on when the other 25% had acquired their stock, wouldn't it in answer of Mr. Justice Blackmun's question?

context.speaker: James V. Ryan
context.text: It could, if they acquired their stock after the events, they would have the same disability that Amoskeag would have, but I assumed --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In contrary?

Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor.speaker: Justice Burger
Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor.case_name: Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor & Aroostook Railroad Company
Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 19, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of 73-718, Bangor Punta Operations against Bangor & Aroostook Railroad will be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: It involves an action my Maine Railroad Corporation seeking damages from its former owner Bangor Punta Cooperation for alleged acts of corporate mismanagement, acts which took place during the period in which Bangor Punta controlled the railroad.

Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor.speaker: Justice Powell
Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor.case_name: Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor & Aroostook Railroad Company
Bangor Punta Operations, Inc. v. Bangor.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 19, 1974

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: But Amoskeag alleges no fraud in the purchase transaction and it has suffered no injury or breach of any legal duty owed it yet.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We hold that under traditional principles of equity, Amoskeag is not entitled to a windfall recovery under these circumstances.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Douglas, Brennan and White have joined.

Beasley v. Food Fair of North Carolina,.speaker: Justice Burger
Beasley v. Food Fair of North Carolina,.case_name: Beasley v. Food Fair of North Carolina, Inc.
Beasley v. Food Fair of North Carolina,.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 15, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of two cases 72-1597, Beasley against Food Fair of North Carolina and 73-157, Calero-Toledo against Pearson Yacht Leasing Co will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In the first, the Beasley case, the Supreme Court of North Carolina held that supervisors discharged for union membership, could not sue their employer for damages under a state statute, creating a right or action for damages for persons discharged for union membership.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Supreme Court of North Carolina held that the enforcement of the state law in favor of discharged supervisors was barred by a provision of Section 14 (a) of the Taft-Hartley Act that provides, “No employer shall be compelled to being supervisors as employees for the purpose of any law, even national or local, relating to collective bargains.”

context.speaker: Leonard Sarner
context.text: I mean the Court of Appeals have had no way of difficulty with that concept that Mal Brothers, you have the Silverstein case where you have limited partners with 60-70 limited partners activities of capitalization of several millions of the dollars.

context.speaker: Leonard Sarner
context.text: You admit here of an economically influential unincorporated association.

context.speaker: Leonard Sarner
context.text: If Your Honors --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Sarner, after Justice Blackmun’s earlier question to you about whether Mr. Wolf or Mr. Kolsby did consent, I went back to the appendix and I see on A-13 of the Government and its memorandum alleged that authorization was given by Mr. Herbert F. Kolsby and Edward L. Wolf for the grand juries to examine those records.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Then on A-22, there’s your motion to quash the subpoena on A-24 is a memorandum in support of the motion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, in one of those two documents that you have, did you traverse that allegation?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition in 73-190, Bellis against the United States; 73-726, Cooper against Kopke; 72-1382, Rich against the United Stated will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In 73-190, Bellis the case is here on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the case, the petitioner is partner in the small law firm, performing as three partner and six other employees including two other attorneys.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This rule had been applied to corporations, labor union, other organizational entities, and we no reason and why it should not be applicable to partnerships as well.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: While the partnership was small, we find that it did have recognized existence of his own apart from tis individual members and that the petitioner was holding the partnership financial records in a representative capacity.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, for the reasons stated more fully in the opinion filed today, we affirmed the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has three opinions for the Court to announce.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Yes, I will announce these opinions in the order in which the case were docketed in this Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The first one then will be 72-1660, the case Stanley Blackledge, Warden against Jimmy Seth Perry.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: A Federal District Court granted habeas corpus that its judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in the written opinion filed today, we agree with the Court of Appeals that it was a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment for the state to up the ante after the respondent appealed his original misdemeanor conviction.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly we affirm the judgment before us.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion and Mr. Justice Powell also dissents upon one of the grounds relied upon by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: A Federal District Court granted habeas corpus that its judgment was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in the written opinion filed today, we agree with the Court of Appeals that it was a violation of the Fourteenth Amendment for the state to up the ante after the respondent appealed his original misdemeanor conviction.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly we affirm the judgment before us.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion and Mr. Justice Powell also dissents upon one of the grounds relied upon by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of the following three opinions, 72-1470, Bob Jones University against Simon; 72-1371, Alexander against Americans United; and 73-5412, Dillard against the Industrial Commission of Virginia will be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The first of these, Bob Jones against Simon, is a case that involves the application of the Anti-Injunction Act of the Internal Revenue Code.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The Internal Revenue Service has a ruling letter program, pursuant to which organizations deemed entitled the tax exempt status are identified.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In this and similar cases, such an action by the Service may result in irreparable laws to an organization largely dependent upon contribution from donors.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: But we are constrained by the explicit language of the Act.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Relieved, if being appropriate, must come from the conveys.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun concurs end results; Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the decision of this case.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In this and similar cases, such an action by the Service may result in irreparable laws to an organization largely dependent upon contribution from donors.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.speaker: Justice White
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.case_name: Bradley v. School Board of the City of Richmond
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 05, 1973

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That this is an unresolved issue of the case, and the question is the applicable law?

context.speaker: George B. Little
context.text: Right, sir.

context.speaker: George B. Little
context.text: Then you have to go to the congressional intent --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: How do you answer Mr. Justice Rehnquist’s question now?

context.speaker: George B. Little
context.text: That I say you have to, under the rule of Peggy Schooner and Thorpe that you start with a presumption against retroactivity.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Do you rely on the Schooner Peggy for the so-called rule of presumption against retroactivity?

Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.speaker: Justice Burger
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.case_name: Bradley v. School Board of the City of Richmond
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 15, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 72-1322, Bradley against of the School Board of Richmond will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It is still another chapter in the rather protracted litigation resulting -- relating really to the segregation and desegregation of the Richmond, Virginia Public School.

Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.speaker: Justice Blackmun
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.case_name: Bradley v. School Board of the City of Richmond
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 15, 1974

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It also rejected the other equitable grounds proposed in the support of the award.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today, we hold that the new statute may be applied that cover attorney’s services rendered before the statute was enacted and when the issue of the propriety of the award was pending resolution on appeal.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In reaching this conclusion, we rely on the established principle that an Appellate Court is to apply the law in affect at the time it renders its decision.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This has its foundation in a case called United States against Schooner Peggy decided here almost 175 years ago with an opinion written by Chief Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: That case draws some exceptions to the rule, but we conclude that it does -- with this case, does not fit those exceptions.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We hold furthermore that the Court of Appeals was not correct when it held that the technical requirements of the new statute were not fulfilled in this case.

Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.speaker: Justice Blackmun
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.case_name: Bradley v. School Board of the City of Richmond
Bradley v. School Board of the City of R.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 15, 1974

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: That case draws some exceptions to the rule, but we conclude that it does -- with this case, does not fit those exceptions.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We hold furthermore that the Court of Appeals was not correct when it held that the technical requirements of the new statute were not fulfilled in this case.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore vacated and the case is remanded for further proceedings as we have directed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

Calero-Toledo v. Pearson Yacht Leasing C.speaker: Justice Brennan
Calero-Toledo v. Pearson Yacht Leasing C.case_name: Calero-Toledo v. Pearson Yacht Leasing Company
Calero-Toledo v. Pearson Yacht Leasing C.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 15, 1974

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The authorities gave no prior notice of their intent to seize the yacht and appellee, the lessor, was innocent of any knowledge of the lessee’s wrongful use of it.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Three-Judge Court held that the statute’s failure to provide  for  pre-seizure notice rendered them unconstitutional for lack of procedural due process and further held that it is applied in forfeit the interest of the lessor, innocent of knowledge of wrongful use, the statute is unconstitutionally deprived an innocent party of property without just compensation.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We disagree, and for reasons expressed in the opinion filed today, reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice White filed a concurring opinion, in which Mr. Justice Powell has joined; Mr. Justice Douglas dissents and has filed a dissenting opinion; Mr. Justice Stewart joins parts one and two of the Court's opinion, but for the reasons stated in the dissenting opinion of Mr. Justice Douglas, he would hold that the forfeiture of property belonging to an innocent and non negligent owner violates the Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: There's nothing in evidence on that on the record, that is correct.

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: The --

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: At least you surprised me by your answer.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I had assumed as I think Mr. Justice Powell assumed from our part of the country that all banks kept microfilms of all checks, maybe California is different.

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: That is not -- that is simply not the case.

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: As a matter of fact, one of the primary reasons for this legislation given by the Government at the time it was being proposed was that banks did not keep the records, and therefore, they found it difficult when subpoenaing records in the investigation of certain alleged crimes to obtain the records in question and it was -- that was part of the purposes or motivation for this.

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: And unlike the case, for example the tax laws or some of the other civil regulatory laws in which recordkeeping or reporting by the entity involved appears to be absolutely essential to its enforcement.

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: The sheer arrest records that are available and to some extent are quoted in our brief would suggest that this not the only way in which the criminal and civil and regulatory laws of the United States can be enforced.

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: They happen to be at least in their judgment essential to those other laws, but not in this case.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Anderson the colloquy between you and Mr. Justice Stewart, does this imply that insofar as these recordkeeping requirements are in aid of the internal revenue laws, you don’t object to them?

context.speaker: John H. Anderson
context.text: No, I object to the recordkeeping because I believe -- excuse me, I see the (Voice Overlap) --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: No, I know, it extends to more just a tax but it also -- among those things that you cited was taxed.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: So that we -- won’t need to return to them unless there are further questions --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Wallace, I do have one more question about the recordkeeping provisions.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I get the impression from your argument that there was -- at least some testimony before Congress to the effect that banks were shifting away from retaining these records.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The reason I ask is because my own experience in private practice is just what Justice White and Justice Powell intimated in their questions that I can’t remember ever having any trouble subpoenaing a check record from a bank.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It seems to me that in my own little locale, they kept them several years.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So, was this in effect an effort by Congress to see that a -- what had been an adequate voluntary system was preserved when there was an impetuous to turn away from it?

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: So that we -- won’t need to return to them unless there are further questions --

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Wallace, I do have one more question about the recordkeeping provisions.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I get the impression from your argument that there was -- at least some testimony before Congress to the effect that banks were shifting away from retaining these records.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The reason I ask is because my own experience in private practice is just what Justice White and Justice Powell intimated in their questions that I can’t remember ever having any trouble subpoenaing a check record from a bank.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It seems to me that in my own little locale, they kept them several years.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So, was this in effect an effort by Congress to see that a -- what had been an adequate voluntary system was preserved when there was an impetuous to turn away from it?

context.speaker: Charles C. Marson
context.text: The Congress has every bit of the plenary power over the telephone company as it does over the banks.

context.speaker: Charles C. Marson
context.text: If tomorrow somebody invented the technology to record all calls and if the day after Congress passed an Act called the Telephone Secrecy Act which required them to do so and then the Solicitor General defended the Act on the ground that the Government had plenary regulatory power over the telephone company and that the parties who were engaged in those calls had no interest in those calls that they were third party business records, that they were not reached under Couch and Donaldson, then that theory which is identical to this theory except the technology isn’t here yet, then that theory would wipe out Katz and Burger and U.S. v. U.S.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, then but the -- it wouldn’t wipe out the Fourth and Fifth Amendment objections, but I don’t see that the telephone notion is particularly objectionable on the commerce clause grounds.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It seems to me that in response to Justice Stewart’s question, you say, you’re arguing Fourth and Fifth Amendment restrictions rather than lack of affirmative authority under commerce? --

context.speaker: Charles C. Marson
context.text: I agree with that, yes sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: For the purposes of the commerce clause conceivably, the Government want -- might want to find out whether the telephone company is reporting accurately all their long distance calls but by merely measuring them and under the commerce clause that would not be a -- probably would not -- the objection --

context.speaker: Charles C. Marson
context.text: I agree with that, yes sir.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: For the purposes of the commerce clause conceivably, the Government want -- might want to find out whether the telephone company is reporting accurately all their long distance calls but by merely measuring them and under the commerce clause that would not be a -- probably would not -- the objection --

context.speaker: Charles C. Marson
context.text: For the purpose that you’ve stated, it would not but nobody claims here except --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: As Justice Rehnquist suggested then you get into the taking the commerce, the content of the communication down then something other than the commerce clause comes into play.

context.speaker: Charles C. Marson
context.text: Well, certainly the Fourth Amendment does as this Court has frequently decided.

context.speaker: Charles C. Marson
context.text: It is the suggestion of the Government that -- because they serve multiple purposes here that the criminal law aspect of this legislation can be ignored notwithstanding its primacy in the legislative history, in the Act and then Government’s opening brief.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of 72-985, 10-73, 11-96, California Bankers against Shultz, Shultz against California Bankers and Stark against Shultz will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: These appeals raise various questions concerning the constitutionality of the Bank Secrecy Act of 1970.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: That Act of the implementing regulations, promulgated by the Secretary of the Treasury, requires in Title I that certain financial institutions maintain records of their customers’ identities and make copies of certain checks and other instruments; Title II of the Act requires the reporting of certain foreign and domestic financial transactions.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We hold that the domestic reporting requirements violate no Fourth Amendment right of the banks to make the reports.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In addition, we hold that the depositor plaintiffs below made insufficient allegations of engagement in domestic currency transactions to challenge the domestic reporting provisions.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the District Court is affirmed on the appeal of the banks and depositor plaintiffs and reversed on the Government’s appeal and remanded for disposition consistent with the opinion filed today.

context.speaker: Bruce A. Campbell
context.text: I might have in my possession the combination to a safe.

context.speaker: Bruce A. Campbell
context.text: I do not believe that that means that that safe, if it can be located, can be opened merely because I had a list of numbers in my pocket.

context.speaker: Bruce A. Campbell
context.text: There is nothing about the key in the example that you pose that takes over the identity of the object that is later searched and seized.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let me give you a slight variation of Justice Stewart’s hypothetical.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Instead of a key to locker at a train station or airport or some such place, they found a pawnshop ticket dated two days before the time of the interview.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And the pawnshop ticket showed that a pistol had been pawned and police were involved in trying to check out pistols and ballistic tests.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Federal District Court concluded that the seizure of the automobile in examination of its exterior violated Lewis’ rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments and that the evidence obtained from the examination should have been excluded at the trial.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Court of Appeals affirmed, holding that the scraping of the paint was a search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment, that the search was not incident to the arrest, and that the car’s seizure could not be justified on the ground that it was an instrumentality of the crime in plain view.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In a plurality opinion, in which the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist joined, four of us conclude that the examination of the exterior of the automobile was reasonable and invaded no right of privacy that the requirement of a search warrant was meant to protect, particularly where the so-called search was made as here on the basis of probable cause and was of a movable automobile.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We also conclude that under the circumstances of this case, the seizure, by impounding the car, was not unreasonable.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: He is of the view that the inquiry of a Federal Court on habeas of a state prisoner’s Fourth Amendment claim should be confined solely to the question whether the defendant had an opportunity in the state courts to raise his claim and have it adjudicated fairly there.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Thus, he would reverse the judgment because Mr. Lewis does not contend that he was denied that opportunity.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: He is of the view that the inquiry of a Federal Court on habeas of a state prisoner’s Fourth Amendment claim should be confined solely to the question whether the defendant had an opportunity in the state courts to raise his claim and have it adjudicated fairly there.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Thus, he would reverse the judgment because Mr. Lewis does not contend that he was denied that opportunity.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: There is a dissent which will be announced.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Marshall and I respectfully dissent from the opinion and judgment of the Court in this case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The most fundamental rule in this area of constitutional law is that searches and seizures conducted outside the judicial process, i.e., without a warrant issued by a judge or a magistrate are unconstitutional, subject only to a few specifically established and well-delineated exceptions.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Since there was no warrant authorizing the seizure or the search in this case and since none of the specifically established and well-delineated exceptions to the warrant requirement existed on the facts of this record, we are convinced that the judgment of the Court of Appeals should be affirmed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The term at least modifying five years is not in the 6330, is it?

context.speaker: Arthur B. Hanson
context.text: Well, no Your Honor it is not but it says, “An enlisted member of the Regular Navy or the Naval Reserve who’s completed 20 or more years of active service in the armed forces may, at his request, be transferred to the Fleet Reserve.”

context.speaker: Arthur B. Hanson
context.text: Then they say for the purposes of this, they left them out in 19-and-a-half years and one day.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, as Mr. Justice Blackmun said, if you had that kind of a provision in 687, you would have a different --

context.speaker: Arthur B. Hanson
context.text: Well, possibly Your Honor.

context.speaker: Arthur B. Hanson
context.text: But I would suggest that when they said at least five years of continuous active duty and then they come down and tell me that for purposes of this subsection that a part of a year that’s six months or more is counted as a whole year, then he has completed at least five years of active duty.

context.speaker: William A. Dougherty
context.text: And it is 10 U.S.C. 277.

context.speaker: William A. Dougherty
context.text: And its states that the laws applying to both regulars and reserves shall be administered without discrimination, (1) among regulars; (2) among reserves; and (3) between regulars and reserves.

context.speaker: William A. Dougherty
context.text: And I’m submitting that there's a different treatment of reserves in 6330 than there is in 67 (a) and that contravenes the statute that I have just cited.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Does that help your case any Mr. Dougherty that the statute Justice Stewart just cited to you contains an expressed provision for rounding out when there's less than the full period and the statute contains no such rounding out provision?

context.speaker: William A. Dougherty
context.text: Mr. Chief Justice, it’s our position that the “rounding” provisions of both statutes are exactly the same.

context.speaker: William A. Dougherty
context.text: The only difference is the term at least five years as you asked earlier and in reference to 20 years.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 73-604, Cass against the United States and 73-5661, Adams against the Secretary of the Navy will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: These cases come here on certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That court disagreed with court of claims on the interpretation of a Federal Statute granting readjustment paid to certain reserve officers when they are involuntarily released from the service.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That court disagreed with court of claims on the interpretation of a Federal Statute granting readjustment paid to certain reserve officers when they are involuntarily released from the service.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The question is the length of time that an officer must serve before qualifying for readjustment to pay.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: For the reasons stated in an opinion we have filed, we agree with Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and therefore affirm the judgment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas dissents.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: He agrees with the Court of Claims and would reverse of Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 72-593, Central Tablet Company against The United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well this is an income tax case coming to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Section 337 of the Federal Internal Revenue Code, provides that gain or loss to a corporation from a sale or exchange of property taking place during a twelve months period, following the corporation’s adoption of a plan of complete liquidation, is not to be recognized or in other words, is tax free to the corporation.

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans
context.text: If Christian and Green had invoked the procedures it may be that their employing agencies would have agreed that they had a mistake and would have corrected the findings.

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans
context.text: If that were the result, this Court or no court would have had to intervene.

context.speaker: Mark L. Evans
context.text: There would have been no judicial issue.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, if exhaustion is a matter of defense, I suppose Justice Marshall is quite right that some of the government should’ve raised by way of an answer to the complaint.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: On the other hand, if it’s a prerequisite of being able to proceed with an adjudication, then I suppose the plaintiff has to alleged.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Did you have any citations as to whether which side the line it’s on.

context.text: In the Christian case, first one, two discharged federal probationary employees claimed that in violation of statue and the constitutional process, they were denied unemployment compensation without a hearing on the question of the factual basis for their discharges.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgments and opinions in 72-5704, Christian against New York State Department of Labor and a second case 72-1019 Sea-Land Services against Gaudet will each be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In the Christian case, first one, two discharged federal probationary employees claimed that in violation of statue and the constitutional process, they were denied unemployment compensation without a hearing on the question of the factual basis for their discharges.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: A three-judge court of the Southern district of New York dismissed the suit without addressing the statutory or constitutional claims.

City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corpo.speaker: Justice Burger
City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corpo.case_name: City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corporation
City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corpo.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 10, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of 73-582, Pittsburgh against Alco Parking Corporation and two companion -- two other cases which are related 72-1490 and 72-1491 FPC against Texaco and Dougherty against Texaco will each be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Pittsburgh case comes here from the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: That court invalidated a taxing ordinance in the city of Pittsburgh.

City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corpo.speaker: Justice White
City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corpo.case_name: City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corporation
City of Pittsburgh v. Alco Parking Corpo.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 10, 1974

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Supreme Court of Pennsylvania held that the tax was unduly high and that when combined with some other stiff competition from the city zone parking lots, the tax wasn’t equivalent to an uncompensated confiscation of the property contrary to the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We reverse the judgment of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Under our prior cases, we do not think the city of Pittsburgh exceeded its powers under the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell has filed a concurring opinion in this case.

Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur.case_name: Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur
Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 15, 1973

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Give me an example.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, with a broken leg you don’t have the anticipated disability long in advance.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It seems to me that the state is arguing that pregnancy combines possible disability during the term plus an anticipated death and a disability at a given time.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And I think Justice Stewart and Justice White have both asked if you claim this as sex discriminatory, give us an example of something else the state should have included in this that represents all those things and that they didn’t and I have yet to hear your answer to that.

context.speaker: Philip J. Hirschkop
context.text: I can only refer you to Judge Winter’s dissenting opinion where he does indicate some medical disabilities that men suffer.

context.speaker: Philip J. Hirschkop
context.text: But again I point Your Honor to the fact that we are making an assumption that woman can’t teach during pregnancy, which the record is the opposite of.

Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 21, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 77 -- 72-777, Cleveland Board of Education against Lafleur, along the 72-1129, Cohen against Chesterfield County School Board will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The respondents in number 72-777 were female public school teachers employed by the Board of Education of Cleveland, Ohio.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The petitioner in number 72-1129 was a female school teacher employed by the School Board of Chesterfield County, Virginia.

Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur.speaker: Justice Stewart
Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur.case_name: Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur
Cleveland Board of Education v. LaFleur.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 21, 1974

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons stated in detail in the written opinion filed today, we hold that the mandatory termination provisions of the Cleveland and Chesterfield County Maternity regulations violate the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment because of their use of unwarranted conclusive presumptions that seriously burden the exercise of protected constitutional liberty.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly the judgment in number 72-777 is affirmed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The judgment in 72-1129 is reversed and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit for further proceedings consistent with the Court's written opinion.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas concurs in the result.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell also concurs in the result and he has filed a separate opinion setting out his views.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion, in which the Chief Justice has joined.

context.speaker: Robert L. Eberhardt
context.text: We did argue that among other things.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And we have no way of knowing.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: I see that Judge Mandarino was the only the dissenter.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Whereas in the first trial Mr. Justice Roberts and I think Mr. Justice O’Brien took the view that they concurred only because Bloom was not retroactive.

context.speaker: Robert L. Eberhardt
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But how are we to read this judgment of contempt that are affirmed on the second go around?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Here the contemnors were two defendants at the criminal trial who were acting as their own attorney and who were found guilty of criminal contempt after trial for several acts that occurred during the trial.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We hold that in the case of post-verdict adjudications of various acts of contempt, committed during trial, the Sixth Amendment requires a jury trial, the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments require a jury trial, if the sentences imposed aggregate more than six months, even though no sentence for more than six months is imposed for any one act of contempt.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We accordingly reverse the judgment of the Supreme Court of Pennsylvania which had held that the jury trial was not required.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I have filed an opinion in which Mr. Justice Douglas, Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Powell joined.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall joins in parts one and three.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: He has filed a concurring opinion.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.speaker: Justice Burger
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.case_name: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idaho Power Company
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 24, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of Number 73-263, Commissioner of Internal Revenue against Idaho Power Company, will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This is a Federal income tax case coming to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Idaho Power Company is a corporation tax payer.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.speaker: Justice Blackmun
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.case_name: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idaho Power Company
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 24, 1974

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We granted certiorari because the Ninth circuit declined to follow a Court of Claims decision on the issue that appear to go the other way.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We reversed the Court of Appeals and hold that the equipment depreciation allocable to the taxpayer’s construction of capital facilities must be capitalized under Section 263 and is not allowable as a deduction under Section 167.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Our reasons for this conclusion are set forth in some detail in the opinion filed today.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I am authorized to say that Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Blackmun.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.speaker: Justice Burger
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idah.case_name: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Idaho Power Company

context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Blackmun.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Nati.speaker: Justice Burger
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Nati.case_name: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. National Alfalfa Dehydrating & Milling Company
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Nati.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 28, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 73-9, CIR against the National Alfalfa Dehydrating and Milling Company will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Well, this is a tax case coming to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We granted certiorari on the petition of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue because of an indicated conflict with decisions of the Court of Claims.

Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Nati.speaker: Justice Blackmun
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Nati.case_name: Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. National Alfalfa Dehydrating & Milling Company
Commissioner of Internal Revenue v. Nati.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 28, 1974

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Court of Appeals, however, by divided vote reversed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today, we hold that the taxpayer did not incur amortizable debt discount upon the exchange of its debentures for its outstanding preferred.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The reasons are set forth in the opinion at some length and accordingly the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart concurs in the judgment in parts one, two and three of the opinion that has been filed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The reasons are set forth in the opinion at some length and accordingly the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart concurs in the judgment in parts one, two and three of the opinion that has been filed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We conclude that the Anti-Injunction Act applies even when constitutional issues are raised by the taxpayer.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We hold that the Act also is applicable even though the tax consequences affect primarily the donors rather than the organization holding the ruling letter.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion; Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in the decision of the case.

Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.case_name: Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 16, 1973

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Rosen on the abstention point theory because I am a circuit justice for the Seventh Circuit, I remember a little about this case last fall and it kind of came up very rapidly as I recall and so that the abstention probably was at least thought to be practical at the time.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You needed a decision rather and elect -- the election board needed some of the advice for it? Is that a fair statement?

context.speaker: Sanford Jay Rosen
context.text: That is a fair statement, but I really not quite understanding the question or how it is from you.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, Justice Stewart inquired whether anyone had suggested abstention in the case, Then the District Court abstaining to get a binding construction of the statute from the Indiana Supreme Court and my recollection is that this was all pretty much a day-to-day proceeding.

context.speaker: Sanford Jay Rosen
context.text: Indeed it was very much a day-to-day proceeding with the party being put to fairly substantial deadline which he undertook too to me.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well in the board too?

Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.speaker: Justice Burger
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.case_name: Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 09, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 72-1040, Communist Party of Indiana against Whitcomb, Governor of Indiana will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, a three-judge District Court for the Northern District of Indiana sustained the constitutionality of an Indiana statute which denied a new political party a place on the ballot, unless its officers filed an affidavit that the party does not advocate the overthrow of local state or national government by force or violence.

Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.speaker: Justice Burger
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.case_name: Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 09, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 72-1040, Communist Party of Indiana against Whitcomb, Governor of Indiana will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, a three-judge District Court for the Northern District of Indiana sustained the constitutionality of an Indiana statute which denied a new political party a place on the ballot, unless its officers filed an affidavit that the party does not advocate the overthrow of local state or national government by force or violence.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse.

Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.speaker: Justice Brennan
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.case_name: Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb
Communist Party of Indiana v. Whitcomb.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 09, 1974

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, a three-judge District Court for the Northern District of Indiana sustained the constitutionality of an Indiana statute which denied a new political party a place on the ballot, unless its officers filed an affidavit that the party does not advocate the overthrow of local state or national government by force or violence.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that the Indiana statute is unconstitutional.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Powell joined by the Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist, has filed an opinion concurring in the reversal, but on a different ground.

Cooper Stevedoring Company, Inc. v. Frit.speaker: Justice Marshall
Cooper Stevedoring Company, Inc. v. Frit.case_name: Cooper Stevedoring Company, Inc. v. Fritz Kopke, Inc.
Cooper Stevedoring Company, Inc. v. Frit.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 28, 1974

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We granted certiorari to consider petitioner's contention that the award of contribution between joint tortfeasors in this noncollision maritime case was inconsistent with earlier decision to this Court.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: For the reasons set forth in the opinion filed over the clerk today, we hold that on the facts in this case, it was proper for the courts below to have applied to well-established maritime rule allowing contribution between joint tortfeasors.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals therefore is accordingly affirmed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has three judgments and opinions of the Court to announce.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: First, I have the opinion and judgment in Number 73-29, Corning Glass Works versus Brennan, and 73-695, Brennan against the Corning Glass Works.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: These cases are here on writs of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: But the reason set forth in an opinion filed with the clerk today, we agree with the Second Circuit; the night inspection work is performed under similar working conditions to day inspection work, as the words “working conditions” are used in the Act.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We, therefore, conclude that Corning violated the Act by paying women less than men for equal work. We also hold that Corning could not remediate this violation except by raising the wages of female day shift inspectors.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Therefore, the judgment in Number 73-29 is affirmed; the judgment in 73-695 is reversed, and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Chief justice, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have filed dissenting statement.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the decision of these cases.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: But the reason set forth in an opinion filed with the clerk today, we agree with the Second Circuit; the night inspection work is performed under similar working conditions to day inspection work, as the words “working conditions” are used in the Act.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We, therefore, conclude that Corning violated the Act by paying women less than men for equal work. We also hold that Corning could not remediate this violation except by raising the wages of female day shift inspectors.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Therefore, the judgment in Number 73-29 is affirmed; the judgment in 73-695 is reversed, and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Chief justice, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Rehnquist have filed dissenting statement.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the decision of these cases.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Ross R. Runkel
context.text: I don’t think this is a case of perjury, Your Honor, perjury was mentioned by the solicitor.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: What is the difference between that and in saying he is presumed to tell the truth?

context.speaker: Ross R. Runkel
context.text: Truth means what the judge had said it means, which is that that's what the jury is there to find out, is the truth, and truth means objective truth not perjury or lying versus not lying.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Why not the instruction that Justice Marshall just proposed, would you think that was unconstitutional, if the judge reminded them that the witnesses had taken an oath and if they have not told the truth they would be subjected to prosecution for perjury?

context.speaker: Ross R. Runkel
context.text: I think that would -- I wouldn't object to it except that it's not a accurate statement of the law, because not telling the truth is not perjury, perjury is a deliberate and intentional lying on the material facts.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I was taking a shortcut, read that into the instruction.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 72-1148, Cupp against Naughten will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case comes to us on a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Respondent Naughten was convicted in an Oregon State Court for the crime of armed robbery, and his conviction was upheld by the Oregon Appellate Court.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: They have a good deal of latitude to condemn jury instructions given by those courts and to reverse convictions resulting from trials in which those instructions have been given.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But a federal habeas court, reviewing a state conviction, may grant relief only if the asserted errors of constitutional dimension.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We conclude that whatever maybe the shortcomings of this instruction the abstract, when read in the context of the other instructions given by the trial court, it neither shifted the burden of proof to the respondent, no water down the State’s burden of proving guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We, therefore, reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals. Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall joined.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: It removes community prejudice from the proceedings and so forth.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: That's why I [Laughter Attempt] I really don't understand why you are so hesitant about urging on this that, if this -- to the extent the statute rests on Thirteenth and Fourteenth Amendments, that the Congressional power under Sections 2 and 5 respectively can even go so far as to overwrite.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg
context.text: Well, I will say it certainly goes so far as to overwrite any common law right that is extended by -- that is created by analogic extension and that's all I have to say.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But then you would -- if you agreed with the -- with Justice Brennan, you would probably have to agree then that if Congress purported to be exercising its commerce power, no jury trials in any of those actions either.

context.speaker: Jack Greenberg

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall will announce the disposition of 72-1035, Curtis against Loether.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari from the Court of Appeals of the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The case was brought a Negro woman, who under Section 812 of the Civil Rights Act of 1968, in which she claimed that the defendants had refused to rent an apartment to her on account of her race.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The defendants requested a Jury trial, but this request was denied, and the Trial judge without a Jury found that they had indeed discriminated against the plaintiff and awarded her punitive damages.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit reversed, holding that a Jury trial was required in this action.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In an opinion on file with the clerk today, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit and we hold that the Seventh Amendment entitles either party to demand a Jury Trail in actions for damages under this particular Section of the Civil Rights Act of 1968.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This is a case that is here by way of grant of a petition for a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The petitioner Joseph Anthony Davis was convicted in a Federal District Court in California for violating a provision of the Selective Service Act, and his conviction was thereafter affirmed by the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The District Court denied relief and the Court of Appeals affirmed without considering the merits of his claim on the ground that its previous decision on his direct appeal or as the law of the case and that the Court would not therefore consider his claim that there had subsequently been a change in a law of the circuit which made his conviction invalid.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in some detail in the Court’s written opinion today, we hold that the Court of Appeals was in error in holding that the so-called law of the case precluded Davis from securing relief under Section 2255 on the basis of an intervening change in law.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We further hold that the issue that Davis raises is cognitable in a proceeding under Section 2255 of Title 28 of the United States Code.

context.text: Well, that is not where it is, I think that --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We are satisfied from the record in the present case, however that a regulation authorizing an Indian net fishery for steelhead for the year 1970 in the Puyallup River would have been destructive to the conservation of this steelhead fishery.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And the Department of Games contention that there should be no commercial fishery in the Puyallup River for steelhead should be sustained as for that year.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgments and opinions of the Court in 70-2481, Department of Game of Washington against Puyallup Tribe and 72-746, Puyallup Tribe against the Department of Game will be announced Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: These cases were here before us involved the construction of the Treaty with the Indian, with the Puyallup Tribe which we held previously, in the prior decision, covered commercial fishing by nets and we remanded the case or the cases that were here before for reconsideration by the Washington Supreme Court, reconciling the treaty right to fish by nets in the right to fish by hook and line with the conservation standards that are -- we emphasized exists in the cases that were here before.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: On the remand, the Supreme Court of Washington on consideration of conversation issue, restricted all steelhead fishing in this particular river, the Puyallup river to fishing by hook and line.

context.text: We hold that, that is not consistent with the treaty rights of the Indians.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: The commercial fishing by nets raises considerable problems in connection with the conservation problems that we must remand the case we feel to the Supreme Court of the state Washington so that some equitable solution consistent with the treaty rights can be worked out.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In our consideration of this case, it appeared to the Court that persons aggrieved by such a suspension, need not await the full administrative hearing, but may obtain prompt enforcement of the original award by going directly to the appropriate court.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: If this reading of the Virginia law is correct, it's unnecessary to address the Federal constitutional question presented to us.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment is vacated and the case remanded to the District Court for reconsideration.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 72-1410, Edelman against Jordan will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In this case the respondents who are welfare recipients brought a class action in the Northern District of Illinois, seeking injunctive and declaratory against the Illinois officials administering the Federal State Program of Aid to the aged, blind and disabled.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The respondent contended that the Illinois officials were violating federal law and denying equal protection of the laws by following state regulations that did not comply with the federal time limits, within which participating states had to process and make grants with respect to the AABD applications.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: While a Federal Court may give prospective injunctive relief against the state official under the rationale of Ex parte Young, it may not award retroactive payments payable from public funds in the state treasury unless the state has consented to sue.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Here we hold that the State of Illinois did not waive its Eleventh Amendment immunity by the mere fact that it chose to participate in the AABD program, which is partially funded by the Federal Government.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Accordingly, we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand for further proceedings consistent with the opinion filed today with the clerk.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Brennan have each filed dissenting opinions.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Blackmun joined.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 72-844, Falk against Brennan, will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This is a case which is here by way of writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Secretary of Labor initiated this action against the petitioners who are partners in a real estate management company for an injunction against violations of various provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 as amended.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reason stated in the written opinion, we agree with the Court of Appeals that the petitioners’ business constituted a single enterprise and that they were the employers of the employees in question within the meaning of the Act.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But we hold that the annual gross volume is to be measured by the compensation they receive for their management services, not by the total rentals of the buildings they manage.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly, we vacate the judgment of the Court of Appeals for further proceedings consistent with the written opinion on file with the clerk.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In the second case, the Federal Power Commission established a so-called fee, services rendered to New England Power Company and on review that was set aside by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We reason as to this that the city’s policies contravene an outstanding school desegregation court order intended to perpetuate a dual school system.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The majority of the Court, however, feel that on this record, it is not possible to determine whether nonexclusive use by private school groups in common with others and by non-school groups involve the city so directly in the actions of those users as to warrant court intervention on constitutional grounds.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
