context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 72-702, Golden State Bottling Co. against the Labor Board will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, the National Labor Relations Board orders Golden State Bottling Company to reinstate with backpay an employee Golden State had discharged.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Pending Judicial review of the Board order, Golden State sold its business to All American Beverages.

Golden State Bottling Company, Inc. v. N.speaker: Justice Burger
Golden State Bottling Company, Inc. v. N.case_name: Golden State Bottling Company, Inc. v. National Labor Relations Board
Golden State Bottling Company, Inc. v. N.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 05, 1973

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: There upon the Board conducted a supplemental proceeding and upon finding that All American after its purchase continued the business without interruption or substantial change in operations, held that All American having acquired the business with knowledge of the outstanding court order was also subject to an order directing the reinstatement of the discharged employee.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And therefore the Board entered in order to that affect and also an order that both firms were jointly and severely liable to pay the employee the backpay due.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit agreed with the Board and enforced its order and we in turn agree with the Court of Appeals and affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: He says -- “you serve it any time you want to serve” that is what the magistrate said, “and it’s up to you to determine when you want to serve it,” and the police officers decided that they would rather serve it at night for some reason unknown to you and me.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: Well, let me say this, Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: It is possible that the magistrate could authorize execution at any time of the day or night and that we would agree with you that a particular mode of nighttime execution was illegal not because it violated a statute, but because it was unreasonable and therefore in violation of the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: And didn’t Justice Harlan said that it’s difficult to have to enforce it during the day and, in the privacy of the nighttime, you can do a private arrest.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: Well, of course this brings us to the argument in the sense that, in this particular case, on these facts we’re talking about a kind of search which this court has, in October 1972, determined would not be considered a nighttime search.

context.speaker: Mr. Andrew L. Frey
context.text: I want to make my point.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition in number 72-6902, Gooding against the United States will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case comes here on a writ of certiorari from the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: That Court had reversed the decision of the District Court, which granted petitioner Gooding's motion to suppress evidence found during a search of his apartment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Although the language of the Federal Statute allowing searches for drugs at any time of the day or night, if the Judge or a United States Magistrate is satisfied that there is probable cause to believe that grounds exist for the warrant and for its service at such time, might at first glance seem to require a special showing for night time searches.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We believe closer study of the language in the relevant legislative history do not support that reading.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We therefore hold that 879 (a) requires no special showing for a search at night other than a showing that the contraband is likely to be on the property of person to be searched to that time.

context.speaker: George J. Tichy, II
context.text: No, it didn’t.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: It just said pending the hearing on the temporary injunction you are enjoined from doing such and such.

context.speaker: George J. Tichy, II
context.text: That’s correct, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But your argument I understand from your response to Mr. Justice Brennan’s question is even if it is said, you are enjoined until June 4 or June 7 form doing this, you say that once it went into federal court, you were enjoined in July and August as well.

context.speaker: George J. Tichy, II
context.text: That’s right, Your Honor because it transferred the burden of proceeding because the Union could defend it.

context.speaker: George J. Tichy, II
context.text: We don’t even have to talk about it in a Labor Management context.

context.speaker: Duane B. Beeson
context.text: The propriety of the issues of its injunction, Your Honor turns at all together at different considerations and those which are raised in the motion --on the hearing on the motion to dissolve.

context.speaker: Duane B. Beeson
context.text: We raised the narrow jurisdictional issue as to whether the injunction could be maintained in the Federal District Court.

context.speaker: Duane B. Beeson
context.text: Now with respect to the issuance of a preliminary injunction, I suspect that the considerations which would have been put forth would be those which deal with the nature of the dispute whether or not this was the situation which could or should be arbitrated whether or not the Union and the employers were party to the contract which the petitioners --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: But in terms of Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: When Mr. Justice Blackmun’s language, you could have raised any considerations with respect to the propriety of the restraining order.

context.speaker: Duane B. Beeson
context.text: I doubt it if it would have been appropriate to do so.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition in number 72-1566, Granny Goose Foods against the Brotherhood of Teamsters and others will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We granted certiorari in this case to resolve the conflict among the circuits as to the proper interpretation of Section 1450 of Title 28 of the United States Court which provides that in cases removed from state to Federal Court, state court orders issued prior to the removal, shall remain in effect after removal until modified or dissolved by the Federal Court.

Granny Goose Foods, Inc. v. Teamsters.speaker: Justice Marshall
Granny Goose Foods, Inc. v. Teamsters.case_name: Granny Goose Foods, Inc. v. Teamsters
Granny Goose Foods, Inc. v. Teamsters.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 04, 1974

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Court reasoned that under the limitations imposed by both State and Federal laws for the duration of ex parte temporary restraining orders, the order could not have remained in effect more than 20 days after it was issued.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: It held that Section 1450, was not intended to go along indefinitely for the life of the ex parte temporary restraining orders, and case is removed to Federal Court.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: For the reasons expressed more fully in the opinion filed with the clerk today, we agree with that interpretation of the Ninth Circuit and therefore affirm its judgment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed an opinion concurring in the result, in which the Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Powell joined.

context.speaker: James M. Russ
context.text: No, Your Honor.

context.speaker: James M. Russ
context.text: [Laughter Attempt] Let me go back over the scene again.

context.speaker: James M. Russ
context.text: The point is that on the frisk, if the police -- our position is that the police officer frisked under Terry and felt what he believed to be objectively speaking was a weapon, then he have lawful authority in this minor traffic offense arrest to search further, to remove the weapon from the man’s person and to take control of it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Suppose when he opened that Benson and Hedges box, it is not a pistol, an automatic, as Justice Marshall suggested, but a folding knife, a rather common weapon that folds in these three sections of about two-and-a-half inches each.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Would you say then too that the search was not proper, unreasonable?

context.speaker: James M. Russ
context.text: Well, I am going back to the basic -- putting his hand on the pocket.

context.speaker: Barry Scott Richard
context.text: And of course, in this Court -- what he is asking this Court to do, I think clearly, is impose for the first time upon search incident to arrest the new restrictions which the Court created in Sibron and Peters and Terry.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Yes, but in your brief, you’re rather making the same argument it seems to me and you suggested it in your oral argument, i.e. that this particular search may have been justified because you thought the man was drunk?

context.speaker: Barry Scott Richard
context.text: That’s an additional reason, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I thought your argument was and constitutionally ought to be that Justice Brennan has outlined it that when there is a constitutionally valid arrest, there can be a complete search.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Regardless of what the arrest is for (Voice Overlap) arrest of the man to take him down to the station house in a police car?

context.speaker: Barry Scott Richard
context.text: That is precisely what we’re arguing and I would agree with it.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The petitioner has brought this case, challenging certain New York State welfare regulations on the grounds that the regulations violated Equal Protection Clause and were also inconsistent with the Social Security Act and various implementing regulations.

context.text: The jury's determination that the brochure was obscene was supported by the evidence and was consistent with the Memoirs obscenity formulation.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But that’s a substantive constitutional right you’re talking about there, isn’t it?

context.speaker: Lawrence L. Curtice
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The right to be free from denial of equal protection.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I think the Government argues here and to me with some persuasiveness that Mr. Justice Stewart’s opinions in Perry and Sindermann are basically procedural due process types of situations, where you don’t have any substantive claim.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But there, you have to show some sort of property that’s created by a statute but you’re not attacking really.

context.speaker: Lawrence L. Curtice
context.text: I think that the Roth decision should be extended to the extent that covers claims for property interest which but for the constitutional, -- beyond constitutional statute, they would be entitled to receive those benefits.

context.speaker: Gerald P. Norton
context.text: That’s right.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, conceivably to -- Excuse me.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Excuse me.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Justice Marshall put a question to you or perhaps to one of your friends awhile ago, saying that if the Veterans’ Administration can find educational benefits to those veterans who had served overseas that that might conceivably raise a constitutional question and the three-judge court or a single district judge might conceivably, I take it, decided to call or convene a three-judge court for that purpose, you would not agree with it perhaps?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But I am trying to distinguish that kind of the case, raising what would appear to be a significant constitutional question from the one which you considered insubstantial here.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In short, you wouldn’t say it was an insubstantial claim if the Veterans’ Administration was denying benefits to all veterans except those who went overseas when the statute obviously gives no such authority.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stewart.

Howard Johnson Company, Inc. v. Detroit.speaker: Justice Marshall
Howard Johnson Company, Inc. v. Detroit.case_name: Howard Johnson Company, Inc. v. Detroit Local Joint Executive Board, Hotel & Restaurant Employees & Bartenders International Union, AFL-CIO
Howard Johnson Company, Inc. v. Detroit.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 03, 1974

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: A recent decision in NLRB versus Burns International Security Services establish that Howard Johnson had the right not to hire any of the employees of prior owner and he commences operation of the restaurant and motor lodge with his own workforce.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: That being so, the union's efforts to compel arbitration in the hope that it'd be arbitrated or ought to have Johnson to hire all of the former employees must fail.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Although, we have held that in some circumstances, a successor employer maybe compelled to arbitrate under the collective-bargaining agreement of the predecessor, Burns requires that no obligation arbitrate can be imposed on a successor employer in the absence of a substantial continuity of identity in the workforce before and after the change in ownership.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us from the Unites States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It presents the issue whether a federal statues declaring that it is unlawful knowingly to make a false statement in connection with the acquisition of any fire arm from a licensed dealer, covers the redemption of a fire arm from a pawnshop.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We granted certiorari to resolve a conflict among the circuits on the issue, and in opinion filed today, we examine the language and structure of the Act and its legislative history, and we conclude that the word acquisition, as used in the statued, does include any person who redeems a weapon that has been pawned.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We do not find the statued ambiguous or uncertain.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The Judgment of the Court of Appeal is therefore affirmed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun

context.speaker: Michael David Rosenberg
context.text: Yes, Your Honor and of course I think the format set down in the Frontiero case where the Court affirms that in a situation like this where a program can be nullified or extended, the extension will be granted if it would probably -- if it was likely that Congress would want to maintain the program even with this additional coverage and I can’t see Your Honor how Congress would refuse and deny millions of people benefits just because of few others would get benefits.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: But I gather from what your argument earlier you think the statute on its face reflects a deliberate congressional purpose to exclude.

context.speaker: Michael David Rosenberg
context.text: I do believe that based on the legislative history, we found since the District Court opinion.

context.speaker: Michael David Rosenberg
context.text: I will say we did not present it to the District Court.

context.speaker: Michael David Rosenberg
context.text: It was very hard to come by but from the material we have been able to gather, I do believe now that it was a congressional intention, a deliberate intention to exclude these men.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, now the extension that Justice Harlan suggested in Welsh rested on his feeling that the statute, we then had before as contravened the establishment cause.

context.text: Also, I would like to qualify the statement made that this tax is subject -- real property and personal property are subject to this tax.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: And then, finally, with respect to a point that came out yesterday, recent models for the disposition that appellant seeks in this case include the per curiam opinion last term in New Jersey Welfare Rights Organization against Cahill and early on, Mr. Justice Blackmun’s opinion in Graham against Richardson.

context.text: You at least have to get over that in arguing that the patent laws were intended to preempt state laws?

Kewanee Oil Company v. Bicron Corporatio.speaker: Justice Burger
Kewanee Oil Company v. Bicron Corporatio.case_name: Kewanee Oil Company v. Bicron Corporation
Kewanee Oil Company v. Bicron Corporatio.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 13, 1974

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We have granted the writ of certiorari in this case to resolve the conflict in the circuits on whether state trade secret protection is preempted by operation of the federal patent law.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We conclude that until Congress takes affirmative actions of the contrary, the states should be free to grant protection to trade secrets.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals of the Sixth Circuit is reversed and the case is remanded to the Court of Appeals with directions to reinstate the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed an opinion concurring in the result; Mr. Justice Douglas with whom Mr. Justice Brennan joined, filed a dissenting opinion; Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the decision of the case.

context.text: We have granted the writ of certiorari in this case to resolve the conflict in the circuits on whether state trade secret protection is preempted by operation of the federal patent law.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In this case, the Supreme Court of Ohio held by a divided vote that the Import-Export Clause of the Constitution that is Article 1, Section 10, Clause 2, prevented the state from assessing an ad valorem property tax upon goods specially manufactured by the respondent company for shipment to customers overseas, but temporarily resting in the respondent’s warehouse in Dayton, Ohio.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Since the goods have not yet actually entered into the stream of international commerce, we hold, upon the reasoning and the authority of our prior decisions, that Ohio was constitutionally free to impose a tax upon the goods in question.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Accordingly we reverse the judgment of the Ohio Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Ray Jeffrey Cohen
context.text: There is no bar to voting by past registration.
And that is what they were complaining about.

context.speaker: Ray Jeffrey Cohen
context.text: Perhaps, but Section 201 of the Minnesota code states the requirements for registration and it doesn’t require party affiliation of the --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Those are the so-called open states not as Justice Blackmun said some political theorists and some practitioners think that open state opens the candidate and the party to very dangerous attack on the party system.

context.speaker: Ray Jeffrey Cohen
context.text: But if the argument of party raiding and party integrity is taken to its logical conclusion then if this case is affirmed, there will be a disastrous effect on the political party system in the state of Illinois and South Carolina, Rhode Island and New Jersey which have similar cases that have been decided.
How long was the problem affected Illinois?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Under a provision of the Illinois Election Code a person is prohibited from voting in a primary election of a political party, if he has voted in the primary of any other party within the preceding 23 months.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We noted probable jurisdiction of this appeal from that judgment.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in some detail in the written opinion filed today, we conclude that this provision of Illinois Election Code unconstitutionally infringes upon the right of free political association, protected by the First and Fourteenth Amendments.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The judgment of the District Court is accordingly affirmed.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Chief justice concurs in the result and I am authorized to say that Mr. Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion and that Mr. Justice Rehnquist has also filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Blackmun has joined.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart

context.speaker: Edward H. Steinman
context.text: In our brief, what we have done is we have said that in San Francisco there are approximately 90,000 students who are given instructions from which they can receive educational benefits and opportunities whereas there are 1,800 students who are foreclosed from receiving any opportunity.

context.speaker: Edward H. Steinman
context.text: In essence it’s effect of exclusion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Excuse me.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I never did get your answer to Mr. Justice Stewart on why -- you say the record is just silent on this as to why.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Here, there may be five or 10,000 other ghetto Chinese students who although they come from the ghetto are perfectly competent to learn English, to understand English.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Now what’s the reason about these 1,800?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, just -- that’s a yes or a no?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I don’t mean to press you unduly, but that’s a yes or a no, isn’t it?

context.speaker: Edward H. Steinman
context.text: The answer is yes, that we have a system of education.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And then obviously that that applies, to pursue Mr. Justice Blackmun’s point to Russians, Israelis, Norwegians, Danes etcetera.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There are no -- there is no stopping point, is there?

context.speaker: Edward H. Steinman
context.text: Well, but again we are assuming that the one Russian student in a given community.

context.speaker: Thomas M. O’conner
context.text: And I think the point that say a thousand are left out, shows that and in San Francisco the school board has demonstrated that it considers this a highly important matter, but that with a thousand left out as of now, they cannot be covered because they in the estimation of the school board there are equally important special problems to be covered.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. O’Conner if you lose this case, what will happen? Is the city likely to withdraw all special instruction to all Chinese?

context.speaker: Thomas M. O’conner
context.text: I cannot answer that Mr. Justice Blackmun, except to state that as of now the city is covering over 50% of the $2.7 million that is now spent on this program.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Well, Mr. O’Conner I noticed in the Mr. Pottinger’s brief at footnote 4, at page 12, this I think has a connection with Mr. Justice Blackmun’s question.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It stated that you’re already obligated by contract.You comply with both the regulations and guidelines.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: You contractually agreed to comply with Title VI and all requirements imposed by HEW and immediately to take any measures necessary to effectuate this agreement and Mr. Hahn recites at a case some to county school district for this proposition that that contract is a binding and specifically enforcible, is that so?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: James J. Hagan
context.text: Secondly, to the extent that Florida had never discussed the Diamond rule, it could have been argued I suppose that it was therefore uncertain.

context.speaker: James J. Hagan
context.text: So to that extent, you could either say that Florida law was settled against the respondents or uncertain because they had never discussed Diamond and one could only speculate what they would do if Diamond was argued to them.

context.speaker: James J. Hagan
context.text: But again, even if you argued Diamond on the facts of this case, this is not a Diamond situation.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Hagan, have you answered to Mr. Justice Blackmun?

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Is there any dispute among the parties now that Florida law is --

context.speaker: James J. Hagan
context.text: Yes, I was getting to that, I am sorry Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: James J. Hagan
context.text: Although there was a dispute in the District Court as to the proper choice of law, there was no dispute before the Second Circuit on this point.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And none here of course?

context.speaker: James J. Hagan
context.text: There appears to be none here, no.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In what cases -- go ahead Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: No, I am just going to ask whether Judge Kaufman’s dissent was on the certification issue was really a sua sponte, was this his own idea?

context.speaker: James J. Hagan
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of Number 73-328, Lehman against the City of Shaker Heights, will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us by certiorari from the Supreme Court of the State of Ohio.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It involves basically the right of a candidate for political office to command advertising space in car cards on vehicles of public transportation.

Lehman v. City of Shaker Heights.speaker: Justice Blackmun
Lehman v. City of Shaker Heights.case_name: Lehman v. City of Shaker Heights
Lehman v. City of Shaker Heights.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 25, 1974

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: He brought this suit, challenging the constitutionality of the municipal policy which refuse political advertising but did allow other types of public transit advertising.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The state courts declined to give the petitioner relief and the Ohio Supreme Court, by a four-to-three vote, held specifically that the city’s refusal did not violate a candidate's free speech or equal protection rights.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We affirm that judgment.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I have filed a plurality opinion, joined by the Chief justice, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We conclude that car card space is a not a First Amendment forum and that a city may exercise some discretion with respect to the type of advertising that may be displayed in its vehicles.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We also conclude that here the decision to limit these transit advertisements to innocuous and less controversial commercial and service-oriented advertising serves to minimize chances of abuse or the appearance of political favoritism and the risk of imposing upon a captive audience, and that this involve no First or Fourteenth Amendment violation.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The opinion as I have noted is a plurality one only but not a majority opinion.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a separate opinion concluding that the petitioner, although free to express his views to a willing audience, has no constitutional right to force his message upon a captive audience which uses public transit vehicles as a means of transport, not as a place for discussion.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion and he is joined in that opinion by Mr. Justice Stewart, Mr. Justice Marshall and Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case we reverse appellant's convictions under New Orleans ordinance for addressing vulgar spoken words to a New Orleans police officer.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We conclude that the factors, relied upon by the Court of Appeals, were insufficient to support a conclusion of discrimination, especially with respect to the discretionary appointment by an elected official of a small body, such as a school board or a nominating panel.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The evidence in this case is too fragmentary and speculative to support such a serious triage.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justices Brennan and Marshall fully concurred and in part of which Mr. Justice Douglas concurred.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This is an appeal from a judgment of the Arizona Supreme Court upholding the constitutionality of an Arizona statute which required a year’s residence in a county as a condition to an indigent is receiving nonemergency hospitalization or medical care at county expense.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In an opinion filed today, we reverse that judgment holding that the challenge durational residence requirement violates Equal Protection Clause.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Its asserted purpose of deterring the immigration of indigents is a constitutionally impermissible one.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The other purposes stated by the State for the residence requirement do not satisfy its having the burden of justification.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Arizona Supreme Court is reversed.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Blackmun concur in the result Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a concurring opinion; Mr. Justice Rehnquist has filed a dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Barton
context.text: Well, Your Honor, it is not my opinion that the arbitration clause of the rule was made for the benefit the employee but rather to benefit the members of the New York Stock Exchange because the employee would be compelled to arbitrate before what I consider a less than impartial panel.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Are you speaking of the California law that you were engaged in the colloquy talk with Mr. Justice Stewart waiving the benefits of the California's statute?

context.text: Yes, Well, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Barton
context.text: Yes, Well, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Barton
context.text: When there is a -- I was to say, a body of decision that indicates that an individual may not waive a law inactive for his benefit, that represents public policy.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Barton
context.text: I would say that the California courts would have to consider in a factual context whether or not --.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Then I misunderstood you because I thought you told Justice Stewart in response to his question that he could waive it?

context.speaker: Joseph C. Barton
context.text: Well, the employee could waive it, Your Honor, but whether the California courts would recognize that waiver is a different question.

context.speaker: Joseph C. Barton
context.text: And I should also point out that Rule 347 (b) does conflict.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 70-2312, Merrill Lynch and others against Ware will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals of California of the First Appellate District.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: It is here because of tension between certain rules of the New York Stock Exchange on the one hand, and some California statues on the other.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, I.speaker: Justice Blackmun
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, I.case_name: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. v. Ware
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, I.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1973

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed today, we have reviewed the Silver case, decided here in 1963 and which we feel bears upon the present case to review the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 has amended regulating the business of securities and brokers and dealers, and have reviewed the history and specific provisions of the California statues urged upon us here.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: From all this we conclude that the pertinent rule of the New York Stock Exchange does not preempt contrary state law, that it cannot be categorized as part of a need for uniform national regulation, but there is applicable here the usual principle that federal regulation of the field of commerce shall not be deemed preempt to the state regulatory power in the absence of persuasive reasons, that the application of the California statues here would not unduly burden the interstate commerce.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: From this it follows that the judgment of the Court of Appeal is to be affirmed and it is affirmed.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: I am authorized to state that Mr. Justice Stewart took no part in the decision of this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I also have for announcement number 73-797, Miami Herald Publishing Co. against Tornillo and for reasons stated in an opinion filed today, the judgment of the Supreme Court of Florida is reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan, with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joined, filed a concurring statement.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I also have for announcement number 73-797, Miami Herald Publishing Co. against Tornillo and for reasons stated in an opinion filed today, the judgment of the Supreme Court of Florida is reversed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan, with whom Mr. Justice Rehnquist joined, filed a concurring statement.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice White also filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And then you would say that was admissible?

context.speaker: L. Brooks Patterson
context.text: No, I’m saying that the police do not do that now and they would not do that as long as that particular provision of the Miranda majority is still in force, namely, that when he says, “I don’t want to talk,” the police are instructed to stop their interrogation at that point and allow him to exercise his right.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, just from the point of view, the police has own interest.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I suppose if they did what Justice White is suggesting to you they would do, they give up all chance of using a confession that the man might make?

context.speaker: L. Brooks Patterson
context.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and that the point I was making.

context.speaker: L. Brooks Patterson
context.text: I think, if he supposes that they’re going to deliberately violate the warnings that are required to be given and so forth in the hopes of finding independent evidence.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Of the -- and as they quit interrogating, he certainly isn’t going to give one.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: So, they still have a motive to seek other evidence.

context.speaker: L. Brooks Patterson
context.text: Yes, Mr. Justice but in fact they do stop and they do obey in great majority of the time as many times as we have an influence on them, they'd be prescriptions that have been delineated in the Miranda decision.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thus, you’re still making the distinction I take it between the interrogation that produces a pistol as Justice White suggested and the interrogation that leads to finding a witness who then comes into the Courtroom to testify under oath?

context.speaker: L. Brooks Patterson
context.text: Absolutely, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: L. Brooks Patterson
context.text: That is the premise of our whole second issue that we briefed and argue.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in number 73-482 Michigan against Tucker will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case is here on a writ of certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The respondent who was a defendant arrested and indicted for rape was interrogated prior to this Court's decision Miranda versus Arizona by police officers who advised him of his right to remain silent and his right to counsel, but did not advise him of his right to appointed counsel.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: There is no concern in this case with the evidence derived from respondent's -- no concern that such evidence is in anyway untrustworthy as a result of respondent's failure to receive full warnings.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: To the extent of the exclusionary rule maybe justified on the basis of requiring the government to bear a full burden of investigation, we do not believe that the limited recourse to respondent's statement which is involved in this case violates any provision of the constitution.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart while joining the opinion of the Court has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment in which Mr. Justice Marshall has joined.

context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed an opinion concurring in the judgment in which Mr. Justice Marshall has joined.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed an opinion concurring in a judgment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: To approve the remedy ordered by the court in these circumstances would impose on the 53 outlying districts, not shown to have committed any constitutional violation, a wholly impermissible remedy and one based on a standard and not even hinted at in Brown I and Brown II or any holding of this Court since those cases.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Indeed it was based on a standard which specially said was improper in the Swann case only three years ago.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings so that the segregation already found by the District Court to exist in Detroit can be promptly corrected.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Justices Douglas, Brennan, White and Marshall have filed or joined in dissenting opinions that will now be announced.Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In the absence of Mr. Justice Douglas, I announce on his behalf a dissenting opinion that he has filed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Indeed it was based on a standard which specially said was improper in the Swann case only three years ago.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings so that the segregation already found by the District Court to exist in Detroit can be promptly corrected.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Justices Douglas, Brennan, White and Marshall have filed or joined in dissenting opinions that will now be announced.Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In the absence of Mr. Justice Douglas, I announce on his behalf a dissenting opinion that he has filed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In pertinent part, the dissent reads as follows.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Accordingly, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings so that the segregation already found by the District Court to exist in Detroit can be promptly corrected.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Justices Douglas, Brennan, White and Marshall have filed or joined in dissenting opinions that will now be announced.Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In the absence of Mr. Justice Douglas, I announce on his behalf a dissenting opinion that he has filed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In pertinent part, the dissent reads as follows.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court today denies the District Court authority to fashion a metropolitan remedy.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: No specific plan has yet been adopted.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We are still at an interlocutory stage of a long drawn-out judicial effort at school desegregation.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It is conceivable that ghettos develop on their own without any hint of state action, but since Michigan by one device or another has over the years created black school districts and white school districts, the task of equity is to provide a unitary system for the affected area whereas here, the State washes its hands of its own creations.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In my view, concludes Mr. Justice Douglas, the Court of Appeals acted has responsibly in these cases and we should affirm its judgment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In Brown versus Board of Education, this Court held that segregation of children in public schools on the basis of race deprives Negro children equal education opportunities and therefore denies them the equal protection of the laws under the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This Court recognized then that remedying decades of segregation would not be an easy task.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: But just as the inconvenience of some cannot be allowed to stand in the way of the right of others, so public opposition, no matter how strident, cannot be permitted to divert this Court from the enforcement of the constitutional principles at issue in this case.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Today's holding, in my view is more a reflection of a perceived public mood that we have gone far enough enforcing the Constitution's guarantee of equal justice than it is the product of neutral principles of law.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the short run, it may seem to be the easier course to allow our metropolitan areas to be divided up each into two cities, one white, the other black, but it is a course, I predict, our people will ultimately regret and for these reasons I respectfully dissent.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I also wish to announce that Mr. Justice White has filed a separate dissenting opinion joined by Justices Douglas, Brennan and myself.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Today's holding, in my view is more a reflection of a perceived public mood that we have gone far enough enforcing the Constitution's guarantee of equal justice than it is the product of neutral principles of law.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In the short run, it may seem to be the easier course to allow our metropolitan areas to be divided up each into two cities, one white, the other black, but it is a course, I predict, our people will ultimately regret and for these reasons I respectfully dissent.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: I also wish to announce that Mr. Justice White has filed a separate dissenting opinion joined by Justices Douglas, Brennan and myself.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Marshall.

Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.speaker: Justice Marshall
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.case_name: Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1973

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Under the Louisiana law is that it or not.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: It’s that enough to get it?

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: Your Honor, there’s some question in my mind as to the answer to that question because I --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Well, you have taken the burden of showing us in your answer to Mr. Justice Stewart’s question that this was a fully valid complete ex parte hearing, you’ve taken on that, now, you say you don’t know.

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: Well --

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We won’t take which one you want to stand on?

Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.speaker: Justice Marshall
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.case_name: Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1973

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: One further point that I think deserve to be made in the context of this case and that is the unusual feature of the civil law.

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: Here, the vendor’s lien as in Louisiana Supreme Court has set forth in its opinion is thought to be an important creditor’s right.

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: At the same time, it’s a right that can easily be defeated by the debtor in the event that the debtor transfers the property, the vendor losses the rights as against the property and so that it was for this reason that Louisiana Supreme Court, I believe, took the position that this was an important right that needed to be safeguarded and that there were circumstances in which it could be shown that there was an immediate need for action on the part of the creditor and that it would be appropriate for the government to lend its power to the taking of that action.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: My question is, is justice Stewart’s -- in your appendix C, Supreme Court of Louisiana is the affidavit which uses the language that he might run away with materials and it appears that it’s a form just filled in.

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: Your Honor, what page is that?

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This is the appendix C in the petition for writ of certiorari to the Supreme Court of the State of Louisiana which is on file here in this Court.

Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.speaker: Justice Blackmun
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.case_name: Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 04, 1973

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Right.

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: -- and the request for rehearing was denied.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Right, thank you.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: May I ask -- as a further question along the lines of Mr. Justice White’s inquiry, why you don’t as an alternative take the position of Fuentes should be overrule?

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: After all, it was four to three decision by a -- Court?

context.speaker: Thomas J. O'Sullivan
context.text: Well, Your Honor, I thought about that and I feel disturbed as my brother Hobbs does about the fact that there have been so many other jurisdictions and courts that have passed upon them and have acted upon the decision in the Fuentes case and concluded that it was an appropriate rule in the jurisdictions in which it applied and adopted it.

Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.speaker: Justice Burger
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.case_name: Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: There is an early opportunity for a hearing.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We hold that the statute is constitutional and do not agree that the Fuentes’ case, a recent case in this Court and 407 US requires the invalidation of the Louisiana statute.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Louisiana -- we affirm its judgment.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I have filed a dissenting opinion in the case of Mitchell against W.T. Grant Company.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In my view this case is constitutionally indistinguishable from the case of Fuentes against Shevin, decided by this Court only two years ago and reported in Volume 407 of the United States Reports, and the Court today has simply rejected the reasoning of that case and adopted instead the analysis of the dissenting opinion in that case written by my brother Mr. Justice White.

Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.speaker: Justice Stewart
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.case_name: Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 13, 1974

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Louisiana -- we affirm its judgment.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I have filed a dissenting opinion in the case of Mitchell against W.T. Grant Company.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In my view this case is constitutionally indistinguishable from the case of Fuentes against Shevin, decided by this Court only two years ago and reported in Volume 407 of the United States Reports, and the Court today has simply rejected the reasoning of that case and adopted instead the analysis of the dissenting opinion in that case written by my brother Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: On the reasoning and authority of the Fuentes opinion, I would reverse the judgment before us because the Louisiana sequestration procedure fails to comport with the requirements of due process of law.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: These views are spelled out in some detailed in the written opinion, I have filed today, but I would add an additional word.

Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.speaker: Justice Stewart
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.case_name: Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company
Mitchell v. W. T. Grant Company.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 13, 1974

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The only perceivable change that has occurred since the Fuentes case is in the make up of this Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: A basic change in the law upon a ground, no firmer than a change in this Court’s membership invites the popular misconception that this institution is a little different from the two political branches of government.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: No misconception could do more lasting injury to this Court and to the system of law which it is our abiding mission to serve.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: I am authorized to say that Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshal have joined this dissenting opinion and that Mr. Justice Brennan also agrees that Fuentes versus Shevin requires reversal of the judgment of the Supreme Court of Louisiana.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: I am authorized to say that and Mr. Justice Powell has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in three related cases; 73-437, 457 and 464, Mobile Oil Corporation against the Power Company and Public Service Commission of New York against the Power Company, Municipal Distributor against the Federal Power Commission will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: And these cases we review the affirmance by the Court of Appeals of the Fifth Circuit, the 1971 order of the Federal Power Commission that established an area rate structure for interstate sales of natural gas produced in the Southern Louisiana area.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of three cases will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The first case is a combination of 73-362 and 73-364; Morton against Mancari, and Amerind against Mancari.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us from the United States District Court for the District of New Mexico.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun will announce the disposition of number 72-1052, Morton against Ruiz.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case presents an issue in the administration of the Federal Assistance Program for Needy Indians.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: That issue is whether the General Assistance Benefits are available only to Indians living on reservations in the United States or to put it conversely, whether they are unavailable to Indians who live off, wherever they live, or whether they -- to those who live off although near a reservation.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We look only at the intent of Congress with respect to Indian complainants of the kind in the case before us and we hold that those claimants who are a full-blooded un-assimilated Indians, living in an Indian community near their native reservation, and who maintain close economic and social ties with that reservation, are eligible for the General Assistance Benefits.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We also touch upon the necessity of the Bureau's complying with the requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act when it makes classifications in the administration of General Assistance program.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore affirmed and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Stuart F. Feldstein
context.text: The Government I believe, has suggested this in one paragraph in its brief, but I believe that the legislative history of the Act substantiates the view that it was intended that such guidelines would be set down for all agencies which were both Congressional and executive departments.

context.speaker: Stuart F. Feldstein
context.text: And as such, the guidelines in Budget Bureau A-25 have the agencies that have promulgated fees have attempted to follow these no matter which category they have been in.

context.speaker: Stuart F. Feldstein
context.text: And this was the area which was looked at in fact by the courts in the Aeronautical Radio case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Going back to Mr. Justice White’s question about the posture of Bureau of the Budget Circular, I suppose it’s a fact that all of the agencies must put their budgets through the Bureau of the Budget, and that historically it has been a coordinating agency and because of its authority, shape, and frame the budgets of the agencies, it has considerable leverage, does it not?

context.speaker: Stuart F. Feldstein
context.text: That is correct, yes.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Whether this Congress of course could increase a budget, but to the Budget Bureau has initially a great deal of authority in the way of enforcement here, do they not?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition in 72-948, National Cable Television against the United States, and 72-1162, Federal Power Commission against New England Power, will be announced by Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In these two cases, Mr. Justice Blackmun and Mr. Justice Powell take no part.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In number 948, the first one involving the CATV, a trade association, Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion, which Mr. Justice Brennan joins.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In the second case, Federal Power Commission versus New England Power, Mr. Justice Marshall has concurred in the result in a separate opinion in which Mr. Justice Brennan joins.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: These two cases involve an act passed by Congress in 1952 called the Independent Offices Appropriation Act, which authorize each Federal agency to prescribe by regulation such fee for the agencies services as is determined to be fair and equitable taking into consideration the direct and indirect cost of the Government of the value to the recipient, public policy or interest served, and other pertinent facts.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In the first case, National Cable Television Association case, the Federal Communications Commission established a fee which was challenged in the Court of Appeals in the Fifth Circuit, and the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals sustained the commissions action.

National Cable Television Assn., Inc. v..speaker: Justice Burger
National Cable Television Assn., Inc. v..case_name: National Cable Television Assn., Inc. v. United States
National Cable Television Assn., Inc. v..title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 04, 1974

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In the first case, National Cable Television Association case, the Federal Communications Commission established a fee which was challenged in the Court of Appeals in the Fifth Circuit, and the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals sustained the commissions action.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: In the second case, the Federal Power Commission established the so called fee for service rendered in New England Power company and on review, that was set aside by the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: We conclude for reasons stated in two opinions filed with the clerk that these fees set by these two commissions did not comport with the law or out of line with the requirements of the law, and that both agency actions must be disapproved which results in reversing in the National Cable Television Association case and affirming in the New England Power case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Douglas.

National Labor Relations Board v. Bell A.speaker: Justice Powell

National Labor Relations Board v. Bell A.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - APRIL 23, 1974

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The appropriate question is whether the individual is a managerial employee and this depends not upon his title, but upon his authority and duties.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We do not agree, however, that rule making is required on this issue rather than a case-by-case adjudication.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we affirm in part and reverse in part the decision of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice White filed a dissenting opinion, in which Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice Stewart and Mr. Justice Marshall joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: We reverse the judgment, holding that it involved Section 7 rights for and against union in that the solicitation, not on working our time but it can -- or in working placements on company's property was under circumstances of this case proper for the Board to regulate.

context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in 72-1289, National Railroad Passenger Corporation against the National Association of Passengers will be announced by Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by a way of the write of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The respondent, the National Association of Railroad Passengers, brought this action in the District Court to enjoin the announced discontinuance of certain passenger trains that had previously been operated by the Central of Georgia Railway Company.

National Railroad Passenger Corporation.speaker: Justice Stewart
National Railroad Passenger Corporation.case_name: National Railroad Passenger Corporation v. National Association of Railroad Passengers
National Railroad Passenger Corporation.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 09, 1974

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The District Court held that there is no such right of action and accordingly that court dismissed the complaint.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But the Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the case for trial in the District Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in the written opinion filed today, we hold that the District Court’s judgment was correct, and accordingly we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a concurring opinion; Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion; Mr. Justice Powell took no part in the consideration or decision of the case.

North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.speaker: Justice Burger
North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.case_name: North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder's Drug Stores, Inc.
North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1973

context.speaker: A. William Lucas
context.text: They have no objection in that regard.

context.speaker: A. William Lucas
context.text: In their brief, they admitted that prohibition and physician ownership is a valid purpose.

context.speaker: A. William Lucas
context.text: They recognized that in their briefs.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Going back a minute to these propositions that Mr. Justice Blackmun was inquiring about.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Even if it isn’t demonstrable or provable that these premises on which the legislation was enacted are actually true, isn’t the constitutional question whether a state legislator has the right to think that they have an impact on public health?

context.speaker: A. William Lucas
context.text: I think that’s the plan I am trying to make is that if the believe and that they bought it in, they did believe it to be a rational basis that statute for protection.

North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.speaker: Justice Burger
North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.case_name: North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder's Drug Stores, Inc.
North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 06, 1973

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: All of these factors and not always disclosed in the petitions on that position.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Did you -- I don’t recall, but did you challenge that in any way?

context.speaker: Mart R. Vogel
context.text: No, we did not.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I think as Justice Brennan said, you’d rather consider jurisdiction which would perhaps allow the further examination into that subject.

context.speaker: Mart R. Vogel
context.text: Yes, I am sure that it would allow it and -- well, we overlooked it.

context.speaker: Mart R. Vogel
context.text: We used to be honest about it.

North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.speaker: Justice Burger
North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.case_name: North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder's Drug Stores, Inc.
North Dakota Board of Pharmacy v. Snyder.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - DECEMBER 05, 1973

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment in opinion of the Court in 72-1176, North Dakota State Board of Pharmacy against Snyder’s Drug Stores be announced by Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: This case is here on a petition for certiorari to the Supreme Court of the State of North Dakota.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: North Dakota passed a statute which required a pharmacist, if a corporation, to have a majority of its stock owned by registered pharmacist in good standing.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, it could be a hearing, it could be – don't you – suppose there would be a very serious First Amendment problems if the state purported to tell somebody running for office that he couldn't try to persuade local voters.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: Well, I think methods of persuasion are one thing, but if the deputy Sheriffs would have used something more than persuasion, I think that, that might be a very serious problem.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: But it is a sort of problem with the state cannot deal with, by restrictive means, means consistent with the exercise of fundamental rights.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Suppose your clients having -- presume they got the right to vote for absentee or however to be accomplish is there corollary First Amendment right along the lines Mr. Chief Justice Stewart was suggesting that, that the candidates all appear before them and make speeches so they could be strong about the issues and make intelligent choices.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: Well Your Honor, I think that they already have the means that are necessary to inform themselves.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: They can have access to newspapers, they can receive information through the mails.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But there are other classes of people who are also denied the right to vote.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: Well Your Honor, I am not so sure of that, there are, the New York Court Of Appeals referred to two in particular, they referred to poll watchers and poll watchers can go vote the same as anyone else can.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: It's simply a part time job for the day and you may have to take time on your lunch out of book but so does everybody else.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: How about the classes that Justice Blackmun just mentioned?

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: Well, Your Honor, I think there would be some question with respect to particular classes as to their construction the New York courts would give that class, because if they are going to extend the right to vacationers, it would seem to me and all he have to be is out of county on a vacation.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: It would seem to me that that's quite a broad basis for construing almost anybody as being at least on probably on a vacation.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: If there were none, I think that they would still have to defend against our claim that registration and jail facilities, voting facilities could be set up in the jail.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: I call the court's attention to the case of Love against Hughes in which Federal District Court sitting in Ohio faced exactly, a case almost exactly the same as this case, a challenge to the absentee statutes and a request for any other means, simply directed the sheriff in the Board of elections to establish election facilities in jail by paper ballots and ballot boxes.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: I see no reason why this is unworkable.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, if there were no absentee ballots under Justice White's hypothesis you say that you would still be arguing, they should set up registration facilities in jail which I suppose then they would have to set up under court order registration facilities in hospitals and other places too, so that your clients would have no better claim to vote than other people physically disabled.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: Well Your Honor, I'd have to say frankly that I think they do have a better claim.

context.speaker: William D. Eggers
context.text: They are the only class of citizens that are restrained by the state.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Robert J. O’rourke

context.speaker: Robert J. O’rourke
context.text: And we maintain it’s unrelated to the nature of the suit whether it’s a civil right action or whether it’s a individual action or it’s an action brought by an individual or by a class.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.text: The disposition of the 72-1180 Old Dominion Branch of the National Letter Carriers Association against Austin will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on appeal from the Judge of the Supreme Court of Virginia upholding liable judgments in damages against the appellants, the National Association of Letter Carriers and its Richmond local.

context.text: The local was recognized as exclusive bargaining representative of Postal Workers in Richmond under the provisions of Executive Order 11491, governing Labor Relations and Federal Employment.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Applying the New York Times standard, we find that the liable judgments here cannot stand.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The newsletter’s application of the List of Scabs cannot be actionable, because the use of the use of the word ‘scab’ which is literally and factually accurate, and Federal Labor Law permits the use of epithets of this kind.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Similarly, Jack London’s definition of the scab cannot be the basis for liable judgment, because we do not believe that it conveyed any false representation of fact, but rather the union’s strong disagreement with those who refuse to join the union.

context.text: The internal loyalty and mutual reliance indispensable to the ultimate effectiveness of any military organization can exist only among people who can be counted on to do their duty.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It is, therefore, not only legitimate but essential that in matters of promotion, retention, duty assignment, and internal discipline, evaluations must repeatedly be made of a serviceman's basic character as reflected in his deportment, whether he would be an enlisted man or a commissioned officer.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But we deal here with criminal statutes, and I cannot believe that such meaningless statutes as these can be used to send men to prison under a Constitution that promises due process of law.

context.text: Another argument that the appellant uses is that well, here we have Mr. Patterson who is forced into a JP court and supposedly had a hearing, but yet it wasn’t a fair hearing, so it's no hearing, but to appeal, you’re making the man pay a double bond.

context.speaker: Philip D. Gaujot
context.text: Well, if the Court is to believe that argument, then as has been mentioned earlier, any amount, any fee of any amount would stand in the way not only appeal bond, but you’d have to give an absolute right for everyone to appeal, and therefore, it would necessitate the overruling yourselves and Ortwein v. Schwab, and United States v. Kras, and really what you would be doing is extending the rule (Inaudible).

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Do Mr. Justice Stewart’s questions to Mr. Higinbotham, Mr. Gaujot, suggest any additional ground of mootness to you that perhaps the remedy which he sought if it isn’t going to avail his client anything, perhaps there isn’t any real case or controversy here, because of the pauper status of the petitioner?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In other words, if it doesn’t facilitate this man’s appeal in order to get the double bond provision stricken down and have a single bond substituted for it, is that a real life case and controversy between the JP and Mr. Patterson?

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The plaintiffs brought the suit to challenge the constitutionality under the First and Fourteenth Amendments of a Section of a California Department of Corrections manual, which provides that, “Press and other media interviewers with specific individual inmates will not be permitted.”

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in detail in the written opinion of the Court filed with the clerk today, we hold that the California prison rule does not violate the constitutional rights of either group of plaintiffs and accordingly we affirm in part and reverse in part, the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The plaintiffs brought the suit to challenge the constitutionality under the First and Fourteenth Amendments of a Section of a California Department of Corrections manual, which provides that, “Press and other media interviewers with specific individual inmates will not be permitted.”

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The District Court decided in favor of the inmate plaintiffs and against the media plaintiffs.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in detail in the written opinion of the Court filed with the clerk today, we hold that the California prison rule does not violate the constitutional rights of either group of plaintiffs and accordingly we affirm in part and reverse in part, the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
