context.text: The opinion for the Court will be in 72-6041, Pernell versus Southall Realty will be announced by Mr. Justice Marshall.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: This case is here on certiorari to the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The question presented is whether the Seventh Amendment guarantees the right of trial by jury in civil actions brought in District of Columbia for the recovery of possession of real properties.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: In all of the causes of action developed in common law for the recovery of real property, the parties were entitled to a jury trial.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: We, therefore hold that petitioner was entitled under the Seventh Amendment to a jury trial in this eviction suit.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is reversed and the case is remanded for further proceeding consistent with this opinion.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The Chief Justice and Mr. Justice Douglas concurred in the result.

context.speaker: W. Eric Collins
context.text: Not because they are in prison, although, that is the resultant situation but for this reason.

context.speaker: W. Eric Collins
context.text: As we understand it, the basic underpinning of these rights on which I think it’s Judge Learned Hand said, “if we stake our all in the proposition that in the free society, it is best to expose people to a free market place of ideas and our fundamental belief is that from this clash of beliefs good, bad, and indifferent from this exposure, that ultimately long term such a free society will only choose, or will choose ultimately beliefs which will improve in our wellness, increase or enlightenment and protect the very freedoms that permit them to choose.”

context.speaker: W. Eric Collins
context.text: Put another way, perhaps we might say that the highest aspect of social wisdom is the long-term collective judgment to free people.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: So, Mr. Collins your answer to Mr. Justice Douglas’ start -- question is “yes?”

context.speaker: W. Eric Collins
context.text: Your Honor, the people, the persons who are -- had been convicted and imprisoned have selected themselves out of such a free society.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: When they did do it?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 72-1589, Richardson against Ramirez and 73-507 Hamling against the United States, 73-557, Jenkins against Georgia will each be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In Richardson versus Ramirez, the three individual respondents in the case had been convicted of felonies and had completed the service of their sentences and paroles.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: When they sought to register to vote, county election officials in three California counties in which they resided, refused to register them because the California Constitution and implementing legislation prohibited voting by ex-felons.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We further hold that the California does not violate the Equal Protection Clause by disenfranchising convicted felons who have completed their sentences and paroles.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Section 1 of the Fourteenth Amendment, which contains the Equal Protection Clause could not have been meant to bar outright the disenfranchisement of felons when their disenfranchisement is expressly exempted by Section 2 of the same amendment from the less drastic sanction imposed by that Section for other forms of disenfranchisement.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We further refer to contemporaneous historical materials illuminating understanding of the framers of the amendment in an opinion filed with the clerk today.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting statement.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion, in which Mr. Justice Brennan has joined and in Part 1 (a) of which Mr. Justice Douglas joins.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 73-786, Ross against Moffitt will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case is here on certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which held that the State of North Carolina must furnish a convicted defendant counsel to seek discretionary review of his conviction in Supreme Court of North Carolina and to seek certiorari here.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We had earlier held that the Fourteenth Amendment does require that the State furnish counsel to a convicted defendant for his appeal as of right within the State system, but we conclude here that neither due process nor equal protection require that respondent receive court-appointed counsel for these discretionary appeals.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In addition, we know that the right to seek review in this Court is granted not by any state, but by the federal statute and exists regardless of the willingness of a state to have the decisions of its highest Court reviewed here.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Thus, we do not believe that the Constitution requires the state to appoint counsel for petitions for review in this Court.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit is reversed.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.

context.text: When he is removed, he is of course off the payroll.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: If he wins the appeal that is provided that he shall be paid for the time during which he was suspended, that is, he gets back pay along with his reinstatement.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: That was a remedy that wasn't available before that Act.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Now isn't that by inference, the suggestions that that's the exclusive course as Justice White has pointed out, that Civil Service Commission was given no power to stay and Senator Langer's statement sounds as though, he was telling the Senator is the manager of this Bill, that no one would have the power to stay that early, that first step.

context.speaker: Thomas McGrew
context.text: I thank in context Mr. Chief Justice that it is clear that Senator Langer is not saying that, Senator Langer is stating his understanding of what would happen and what I submit would happen in 999 out of a 1000 cases.

context.speaker: Thomas McGrew
context.text: I don't think he intended that and I don't think that it can be fairly taken in context as a statement on the power of the federal courts, either directly or by inference --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist will announce the opinions in Sampson against Murray and Winward Shipping against American Radio Association.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The case of Sampson against Murray kind of came to us from the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Respondent Sampson was a probationary government employee in the public building services of GSA.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This reluctance has increased in the case when the employee is a probationary employee, a class of employee to whom Congress has extended fewer substantive and procedural rights than to permanent employees.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: When the discharge of such employees is at issue we believe the District Court should play a very restricted role leaving the matter to the Civil Service Commission in all but the most exceptional circumstances until that Commission has had an opportunity to review the validity of a discharge and to contemplate the proper relief if needed.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We accordingly reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

context.speaker: Howard Moore, Jr.
context.text: Injunctive relief immunizes particular conduct by enjoining further prosecution whereas a declaration merely interprets the law and has no injunctive effect.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Of course if you get far enough away from the irreparable harm and the kind of criteria you have for an injunction, then you begin to get into the case and controversy problem that Justice White mentioned, don’t you?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I mean a completely abstract instruction?

context.speaker: Howard Moore, Jr.
context.text: Well, it’s not completely abstract because this Court as well as the statute, the declaratory judgment statute has defined standards to determine when a controversy exists over which the District Court can assume jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 72-5581, Steffel against Thompson will be announced by Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, police officers threatened the petitioner with prosecution under Georgia's criminal trespass law if he didn't stop handbilling at a Georgia shopping center to protest our involvement in Vietnam.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Petitioner thereupon, following the treat, brought this action in federal district of Georgia for judgment declaring that application to him on the Georgia trespass of law would violate his First and Fourteenth Amendment rights.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: District Court dismissed the suit on the ground that in the absence of proof that the police had or would act in bad faith, this Court's 1971 decisions in Younger v. Harris and related cases forbade the District Court from entertaining the suit and the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that federal declaratory relief is not precluded, when a prosecution based upon an assertedly unconstitutional state statute, although threatened, is not in fact begun and therefore is not pending even if a showing of bad faith enforcement or other special circumstances has not been made.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart joined by the Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Rehnquist also joined by the Chief Justice and Mr. Justice White although all joining the court's opinion, have also filed concurring opinions.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: But would you want us to strike that down, that part of it?

context.speaker: Clayton P. Roche
context.text: I would be happy if nothing were struck down, Your Honor but [Laughter Attempt]

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: I suppose your interest is in sustaining the judgment that brought you up here.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: But pursuing Justice Marshall’s question a little bit further, is it possible to readily identify the people who have just voted as Justice Marshall suggested on some of the other issues but not on any part –-

context.speaker: Clayton P. Roche
context.text: Oh!

context.speaker: Clayton P. Roche
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.text: In the Storer and Frommhagen cases there is an appeal from a three-judge District Court judgment, holding various provisions of a California Election Code constitutional.

context.text: The disposition of 72-812, Storer against Brown, 72-6050 Frommhagen against Brown, 72-887, 72-942 American Party of Texas and White and Hainsworth against White and 73-88 U.S. against Edwards will be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.text: In the Storer and Frommhagen cases there is an appeal from a three-judge District Court judgment, holding various provisions of a California Election Code constitutional.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The provisions in general regulate the access of independent candidates to the ballot.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We agree with the District Court that, that provision is valid, but there are other parties to this litigation Messrs Halls and Tyner were barred from the ballot for failure to satisfy the signature requirements in the California Court.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: As to that part of the judgment we vacate it.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We do not decide the merits of the controversy.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: These are to be passed upon in the first instance by the courts below.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore reversed and the case is remanded for further proceedings.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Chief Justice, Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Rehnquist and I respectively disagree with the opinion and judgment of the Court in this case.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Court reverses the Court of Appeals and holds that this case is not moot, despite the fact that the underlying Labor dispute that gave rise to the petitioner's claims ended even before the parties made their initial appearance in the District Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: We think this holding ignores the limitations placed upon the federal judiciary by Article 3 of the Constitution and disregards as well the clear teachings of prior cases.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The doctrine of mootness is already a difficult and complex one and we think that the Court today muddies the waters further by disregarding the doctrine of stare decisis and straining unnecessarily to distinguish and limit some of the few clear and controlling precedents that are available to us.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For these reasons, we agree with the opinion of the Court of Appeals and we would affirm the judgment of that Court.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Our views are set out in more detail in a dissenting opinion I have filed with the clerk today.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Stewart, thank you Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.text: Both the plaintiffs and the defendants petitioned for certiorari, and because of the seemingly important questions of federal law involved, we granted both petitions.

context.text: For the reasons set out in detail in a written opinion filed today, we have concluded that the District Court was correct in holding that the plaintiff’s complaint was barred by this Court’s Fortnightly decision.

context.speaker: Edward R. Korman
context.text: That’s correct because there was no warrant.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, Mr. Korman, in Cooper against California and Katie against Dambrowski, this Court held a search to the reasonable under the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Even though there was no question of probable cause really applicable to that fact situation.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Is your position here that that kind of test is applied or that the kind of test Mr. Justice Stewart suggest of revolting the conscious stomach type of thing in Rochin, is this such a --

context.speaker: Edward R. Korman
context.text: Well, I think it would depend, as I said it would be the kind of test Your Honor is suggesting but also I think the protections of the Fourteenth and Fifth Amendments overlap to a certain extent with the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Edward R. Korman
context.text: And that of course the kind of conduct that was involved in Rochin would clearly come under the Fourth Amendment standard but for example the cases, Your Honor mentioned in Terry where cases which involve reasonableness in the sense that there was a legitimate law enforcement purpose combined with an intrusion, which was something, less than a full scale arrest and seizure of the individual and that it seems to me is what we have here.

context.speaker: Thomas R. Smith
context.text: Yes.
And if that is so then why isn’t the answer to my penitentiary inmates situation exactly the same?

context.speaker: Thomas R. Smith
context.text: It would be if it were taken for the purpose of making a search, we submit that a warrant would be required although plainly in those circumstances it is not taken for the purpose of making a search.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Well, to pursue Mr. Justice Blackmun’s question, suppose that making a search of his clothes when he comes into the prison to be sure that he is not carrying narcotics or any other dangerous material.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: They must get a warrant when he arrives at the prison?

context.speaker: Thomas R. Smith
context.text: No, Your Honor, that is plainly an inventory search.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We in turn reserve the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We hold that the police did no more the day after arrest than they could have done at the time of arrest and that in these circumstances no warrant for seizure of the clothing was required.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed the dissenting setting opinion in which Justices Douglas, Brennan, and Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We hold that the police did no more the day after arrest than they could have done at the time of arrest and that in these circumstances no warrant for seizure of the clothing was required.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The judgment of the Court of Appeals is therefore reversed.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart has filed the dissenting setting opinion in which Justices Douglas, Brennan, and Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

United States v. General Dynamics Corpor.speaker: Justice Stewart
United States v. General Dynamics Corpor.case_name: United States v. General Dynamics Corporation
United States v. General Dynamics Corpor.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 19, 1974

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The government appealed directly to this Court pursuant to the Expediting Act and we noted probable jurisdiction.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: In its long and thorough opinion, the District Court concluded that the evidence did not support the government's contention that the effect of the acquisition might be substantially to lessen competition in any line of commerce, in any section of the country.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For the reasons set out in some detail in the written opinion filed with the clerk today, we hold that this conclusion of the District Court was not erroneous and we accordingly affirm the judgment before us.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Brennan, Mr. Justice White and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The view expressed in the dissenting opinion is that the District Court did not make the findings necessary to determine whether or not this acquisition violated Section 7 and that the case should be remanded to the District Court so that these findings can be laid.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you, Mr. Justice Stewart.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: If as a willful disclosure of a kind that the statute forbids Mr. Justice Douglas, there isn’t.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: How about violations of a procedure, for generating the search?

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: No I doubt Mr. Justice Douglas that I would think that the delegation from this -- I’m sure I would think that the delegation from Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Lindenbaum does not generate either criminal or civil liability and I think the misidentification of Mr. Wilson does not generate either of those varieties --

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Then Justice Stewart was right to get down to those sanctions and unless its suppressed.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: Well Mr. Justice Stewart -- I mean Mr. Justice Douglas, if I may say -- I may say the sanctions have been specified by Congress and the fact that they did not specify this sanction, I think ought to mean something as well as the --

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Well, it means these words are just precatory?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And you say they are not embraced within this political process?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: There’s something less than political but different from career?

context.speaker: H. Russel Smouse
context.text: A stamp of approval has not been placed on them by the Senate in an area where the Senate wanted great care exercise in the authorization of wiretap surveillance.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Then, to pursue Mr. Justice Blackmun’s inquiry a few moments ago, if you had a period where you had an acting Attorney General appointed under a recess appointment, who might act for quite a while as some have, you would be immobilized under the statute.

context.speaker: H. Russel Smouse
context.text: That would easily be met Mr. Chief Justice had his predecessor designated an Assistant Attorney General to exercise authorization in this area and the Congress --

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Wouldn’t you -- wouldn’t the Government immediately run under the proposition that when a principal ceased to hold the power all his agents fell with him?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of 72-1319, United States against Chavez, 72-1057, United States against.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Giordano, and 72-6160, Mitchell against W. T. Grant Co., will each be announced by Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Giordano case number 72-1057 comes here from the Fourth Circuit on certiorari, and Chavez from the Ninth Circuit on -- also on certiorari.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: These two cases raise related questions under the Federal Statute, authorizing official wiretapping under a court order.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The question is whether that procedure comports with the Act, and if it is not whether the evidence obtained from a wiretap under an order that was so authorized is admissible or inadmissible.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We hold that an application approved in that manner does not comply with the Act, and that evidence obtained from a wiretap under such an order, where the application has been so approved, is admissible in evidence.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The Court of Appeals had arrived at the same conclusion, and so we affirm the Court of Appeals.

context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart will announce the disposition of 72-1328, United States against Kahn.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by a way of a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice White.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Stewart will announce the disposition of 72-1328, United States against Kahn.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: This case is here by a way of a writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It involves a wiretap which was placed on the home telephones of one of the respondents, Irving Kahn, pursuant to a court order under Title III of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1970.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The order speaks of conversations of Irving Kahn and others as yet unknown, not of conversations between Irving Kahn and others.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Since Kahn, therefore,  could not communicate except with others, the reading given to the wiretap order by the Court of Appeals would render the others as yet unknown language entirely meaningless.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Consequently, we reversed the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand this case to that court for further proceedings consistent with the written opinion filed with the clerk today.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Douglas has filed a dissenting opinion which Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: I’m not certain Mr. Justice.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, if it’s a new bank, it’s gonna be a new entry?

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: It provides --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist asked you about de novo entry, which is much broader question an entry by an existing organization.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: How many new banks have been organized in Spokane in the last ten years, any?

context.speaker: Daniel M. Friedman
context.text: One new bank that I know.

United States v. Marine Bancorporation,.speaker: Justice Burger
United States v. Marine Bancorporation,.case_name: United States v. Marine Bancorporation, Inc.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition of number 73-38 United States against Marine Bancorporation and 73-767, United States against Connecticut National Bank will be announced by Mr. Justice Powell.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: This is a civil antitrust action under the Section 7 of the Clayton Act brought here on appeal from the District Court for the Western District of Washington.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The issue is the validity of a proposed merger between the second largest banking organization in a State based in Seattle and the eighth largest bank located in Spokane.

United States v. Marine Bancorporation,.speaker: Justice Powell
United States v. Marine Bancorporation,.case_name: United States v. Marine Bancorporation, Inc.
United States v. Marine Bancorporation,.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 26, 1974

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The Government nevertheless contended that entry was feasible, either by acquisition of a small state bank or by achieving an informal de novo entry though establishing a sponsored bank and later acquiring it.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We have carefully examined the record in this case and conclude in accordance with the findings of the District Court that the Government has failed to establish that either of these proposed methods of entry is feasible or that either offers a substantial likelihood of producing pro-competitive effects.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice White filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justices Brennan and Marshall joined; Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in that decision.

context.text: The Government nevertheless contended that entry was feasible, either by acquisition of a small state bank or by achieving an informal de novo entry though establishing a sponsored bank and later acquiring it.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: We have carefully examined the record in this case and conclude in accordance with the findings of the District Court that the Government has failed to establish that either of these proposed methods of entry is feasible or that either offers a substantial likelihood of producing pro-competitive effects.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the District Court.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Mr. Justice White filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justices Brennan and Marshall joined; Mr. Justice Douglas took no part in that decision.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice White will announce the disposition of 72-1355, United States against Matlock.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: In this case, the federal officers seized certain evidence in the course of searching the house.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: They had no warrant, but relied on consent of one of the occupants.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: They had no warrant, but relied on consent of one of the occupants.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: The District Court held that the consent was invalid and suppressed the evidence, Court of Appeals affirmed for the reasons stated in the opinion on file.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: We in turn reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals and remand the case to the District Court for further proceeding.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgments and opinion of the Court in number 72-1168, United States against Maze will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This case involves the question of whether the credit card fraud perpetuated by Thomas Maze, the respondent here, was within the prohibition of the terms of the federal mail fraud statute.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: In the early spring of 1971, Maze forsook the jury climate of the Ohio valley where he lived and went on a trip to the Sun Bell, by presenting a Bank America card which he had purloined from his roommate.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We agree with the Court of Appeals that respondent Maze’s scheme had reached fruition when he checked out of the motels to which he had presented the card.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And the subsequent mailings by the merchants and motel owners cannot be said to be for the purpose of executing his scheme.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We, therefore, affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice White joins.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice White has filed a dissenting opinion in which the Chief Justice Mr. Justice Brennan and Mr. Justice Blackmun join.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And the subsequent mailings by the merchants and motel owners cannot be said to be for the purpose of executing his scheme.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We, therefore, affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Chief Justice has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice White joins.

context.speaker: James St. Clair
context.text: I presume that’s so and he would then -- it would be made available to the Special Prosecutor.

context.speaker: James St. Clair
context.text: The Special Prosecutor says that, of course, this would then become part of the impeachment proceedings, and here we are.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. St. Clair, going back to this murder witness situation.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: If the President, any president, witnessed an automobile accident and was the sole witness of murder, as Mr. Justice Stewart suggested, you’re not indicating that his testimony, his evidence, would not be available to the court but merely that he can’t be subpoenaed but might give it back by deposition as several presidents have in the past.

context.speaker: James St. Clair
context.text: That is quite correct.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The testimony of the Justices of this court has been given in past times by depositions, has it not?

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: First, the Waterman Steamship and Reynolds case were not criminal cases and the government was not in the posture of a third-party in possession of relevant evidence.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Moreover, those cases, as I have noted, involved confidential military and diplomatic information, but here the claim of privilege rests simply on the generalized undifferentiated claim of the need to keep all the presidential communications private and confidential.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We had once recognized the high difference that is due to protect all of the communications of the President.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: As early as the case of United States against Burr, 1807, Chief Justice Marshall sitting as a trial judge had authorised to subpoena to President Jefferson to secure certain letters in the possession of the President.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And Marshall noted, among many other important passages in that opinion that in no case of this kind would a court be required to proceed against the President as against an ordinary individual.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: However, the deference, traditionally shown by the courts toward a President, does not mean that all material in the possession of a President is immune in all circumstances from judicial process.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We conclude, therefore, that when the ground for asserting of the privilege as to subpoenaed materials, sought for use in a criminal trial, is based solely on the generalized interest in confidentiality as distinguished from the situations whereat maybe based upon military secret or diplomatic secrets, it cannot prevail over the fundamental demands of due process of law in the fair administration of criminal justice.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The generalized assertion of privilege must yield to the demonstrated, specific need for the evidence in a pending criminal trial.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Accordingly the judgment under review is affirmed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist took no part in the consideration or decision of these cases.

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: On the separate point at this stage, I am -- the Flast tests drive one into a consideration of what that -- I suppose I am saying the same (Voice Overlap).

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Are you really saying that if we reject standard, we reject your standing argument we are also necessarily rejecting the political question side of your argument?

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: I think that there maybe more to the political question doctrine than that and I would certainly like a chance to explore it below if we -- while the standing here --

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: That gets back to Mr. Justice White’s original question.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: If we were to disagree with you on standing, what not I think go back to the Third Circuit on the question, on the issue of political question?

context.speaker: Robert H. Bork
context.text: Well, since the Third Circuit is already ruled Mr. Justice Brennan that --

context.speaker: Osmond K. Fraenkel
context.text: Because the Constitution provides that Congress shall determine that and the constitution provides that a Justice of this this Court shall be approved by the Senate and having been appointed by the President and approved by the Senate, the constitutional provisions have been complied with, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Similarly the -- at least the claim of the government who would be undoubtedly be if it isn't already that the constitutional clause and question here has been implemented by Congress by a statute tender a general rather than a detailed annual account or periodic account?

context.speaker: Osmond K. Fraenkel
context.text: A particular statute which we say Congress had no power to enact because excluded, it didn’t merely describe categories, but it is excluded an important organ of Government from any disclosure.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But couldn’t it just as well had been argued in Levitt that the Senate had no power to confirm Justice Black because he had voted to increase the emolument of the office which was sum of the constitution then prohibited him from taking?

context.speaker: Osmond K. Fraenkel
context.text: Well, I would say that if the constitution -- provision of the constitution that we are now considering said that the accounts of agencies of the Government shall be published to the extent that Congress may provide.

context.speaker: Osmond K. Fraenkel
context.text: Then of course Congress’ decision could not be subjected in the way that we are attacking here.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: If you find a razor, suppose you find in that cartoon a razor with a small holder so that it could be used as a weapon --

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: Would certain -- which could certainly be introduced an evidence against the person for carrying concealed weapon.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: And would it suggest to the officer as I think Mr. Justice White brought out in the prior case that if the man had an a razor in a holder that could be used as a weapon, he might have some other weapons on him that would justify a more extensive search.

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: That was the point Mr. Justice I -- Mr. Chief Justice, I was trying to make by suggesting that the search of these containers gives the officer information about the kind of possible dangers he maybe facing.

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: I also think that the suggestion that Mr. Justice Marshall made would create substantial custodial problems with the police.

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: That was the point Mr. Justice I -- Mr. Chief Justice, I was trying to make by suggesting that the search of these containers gives the officer information about the kind of possible dangers he maybe facing.

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: I also think that the suggestion that Mr. Justice Marshall made would create substantial custodial problems with the police.

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: In order to be safe, they would have to remove anything that was a closed container from the person arrested and somehow try and handle that while they were handling the individual subject to arrest.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Tuttle, wouldn’t the proposition put to you by Mr. Justice Stewart earlier and put to counsel in the proceeding here by Mr. Justice Brennan that is that where you have a valid arrest, you may have a full field search without further inquiry, solve a lot of the kind of parsing of factual situations and at least offer a certain simplicity of administration (Voice Overlap).

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: Well, we -- we do think that such a rule of course would be understandable and manageable by a police officers attempting to deal with situations on the street.

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle
context.text: And that a rule which required an officer in every instance to determine that a search has an evidentiary purpose or has a weapon’s purses -- purposes perhaps going to con -- be confusing for police officers.

context.speaker: Allan A. Tuttle

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgments and opinions of the Court in number 71-1669, Gustafson against Florida, and 72-936, United States against Robinson, will be announced by Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Robinson case involves the validity of a search of the person incident to a lawful arrest, where after the arrest, the police officer makes a decision to take the person arrested into custody.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Here, a police officer in the District of Columbia arrested respondent Robinson for the crime of operating a motor vehicle after revocation of his operator's permit, in offense defined by statute in the district.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This being the case, it is immaterial whether or not they were potential fruits of the crime for which Robinson was originally arrested, what the probability in this particular situation was that weapons would, in fact, be found upon his person or that the arresting officer in this particular case did not fear Robinson or believe that he was armed.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The search of Robinson's person having been lawful, fruits are contraband such as the heroin capsules could be seized upon being discovered in the course of the lawful search.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: For these reasons, we reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Sager
context.text: We recognize that, says the village, that there may be some single persons who own a house in Belle Terre by themselves and we think it would be unjust to make them move, and we’re concerned that they may be lonely and so we permit them to have one associate.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Sager
context.text: Now, I don’t criticize the policy, let me make clear, of allowing two unrelated persons, but I do want to make it perfectly plain that the village by its own description, of its reason for this exception to the exclusion of single families, does not purport to be saying “yes, we in fact like single -- a traditional -- untraditional household groups, but we want to regulate their size,” rather, it says “we want to keep unrelated persons who form households of such persons out of this community, but we realize the equities become so great in some situations that we make an exception.”

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Sager
context.text: That’s the village’s own characterization of that, accepting, Your Honor, not mine.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Mr. Sager, I’m not sure I attract your response to Mr. Justice Stewart’s question, but let me try another one that might be somewhat like it.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: What about a fraternity house?

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Sager
context.text: Again, Your Honor, I think that the question in each instance would be at a minimum as in any governmental classification which deprives a given group of people of a substantial benefit.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The disposition in number 73-191, Village of Belle Terre against Boraas will be announced by Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: This case involves questions under a village ordinance enacted in New York villages, Village of Belle Terre on Long Island.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: It is a small village of about 700 people.

context.text: We have reversed the Court of Appeals holding that this zoning ordinance is lower than the limits of the police power.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: It’s not countered upon the racial basis and not involving a discrimination in a constitutional sense.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: The views are expressed in an opinion filed with the clerk.

context.speaker: William O. Douglas
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion and Mr. Justice Marshall has filed a separated dissenting opinion.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Douglas.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In this case, the Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit held that the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970, which became effective on May 1, 1971 had repealed provisions of trial law under which drug offenders sentenced before May 1, 1971 were ineligible for consideration for parole.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We disagree and hold that the provisions of the old law are preserved by Section 1103 (a) of a new law and by the general saving statute 1 U.S.C, Section 109.

context.text: We disagree and hold that the provisions of the old law are preserved by Section 1103 (a) of a new law and by the general saving statute 1 U.S.C, Section 109.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We therefore reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

context.text: I think so.

context.speaker: Thomas N. Sullivan
context.text: I mean, that’s what they say in their reply brief.

context.speaker: Thomas N. Sullivan
context.text: They say they determined what the applicable state law is.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Let’s assume what Mr. Justice Brennan just suggested to you, then your position is that merely it would’ve widen the options of available to get this remedial training to the students?

context.speaker: Thomas N. Sullivan
context.text: I would’ve hope that dual enrollment would have been-- provisions would’ve been made for dual enrollment.

context.speaker: Thomas N. Sullivan
context.text: I would’ve hoped that the children could’ve participated and received their genuine opportunities in the language of the guidelines to participate in comparable programs.

context.speaker: Leo Pfeffer
context.text: Yes, it’s contrary to state law whether it’s -- yes.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Your position is that under the state constitution both forms are forbidden?

context.speaker: Leo Pfeffer
context.text: Exactly, and --

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: And which it does bring in under the spotlight Mr. Justice Brennan’s question.

context.speaker: Leo Pfeffer
context.text: Yes.

context.speaker: Leo Pfeffer
context.text: My ultimate position is that, as we interpret the federal statute, the federal statute requires accommodation to state law, constitutional, statutory, and decision.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: The judgment and opinion of the Court in number 73-62 Wheeler against Barrera will be announced by Mr. Justice Blackmun.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: This case comes to us from the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: The petitioners are the State of Missouri and its State Board of Education.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Other aspects of the case, we conclude are not right for review here.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: We emphasize that while the plaintiffs are entitled to comparable services under the statute, they are not entitled to any particular form of service and that it is the role of state and local agencies and not of the federal courts at least at this stage of the litigation to formulate an acceptable and legally suitable plan.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Thus as stated before, the judgment of the Court of Appeals is affirmed, but with some disagreement on our part as to the reasoning by which the court arrived at its result and by a positive assertion on our part that it is Missouri law and not federal law which has to govern on the issue of the legal availability of particular services.

William E. Arnold Company v. Carpenters.speaker: Justice Burger

William E. Arnold Company v. Carpenters.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MAY 20, 1974

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We disagree.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: In a long series of cases we had emphasized that the Congress in enacting Section 301 of the part of the amendments intended that state and federal courts have jurisdiction to enforce collective bargaining contracts providing for arbitration to grievances and to enjoin strikes over such grievances, even if the strikes, by arguably, also constitute unfair labor practice.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We, therefore, unanimously reverse the judgment of the Florida Supreme Court.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: Thank you Mr. Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Texas Trail Court felt that its jurisdiction had been preempted by the National Labor Relations Act.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The Texas Court of Civil Appeals agreed and we ranted certiorari.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: We find that this dispute involving as it did the maritime operations of foreign flag ships was not within the jurisdiction of the National Labor Relations Board, and therefore, we reverse the judgments below.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion in which Mr. Justice Douglas and Mr. Justice Marshall have joined.
